{{Use Australian English|date=September 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''The X Factor'' finalists (Australia season 4)}} The [[The X Factor (Australia season 4)|fourth season]] of ''[[The X Factor (Australian TV series)|The X Factor Australia]]'' was broadcast on the [[Seven Network]]. It premiered on 20 August 2012<ref>{{cite web|last=Knox|first=David|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2012/08/returning-the-x-factor-2.html|title=Returning: The X Factor|publisher=[[TV Tonight]]|date=2012-08-05|accessdate=2012-08-05}}</ref> and ended on 20 November 2012.<ref name="finalresults">{{cite web|last=Knox|first=David|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2012/11/samantha-jade-wins-the-x-factor-2012.html|title=Samantha Jade wins The X Factor 2012|publisher=TV Tonight|date=2012-11-20|accessdate=2012-11-20}}</ref> The show consisted of several stages: auditions, super bootcamp, home visits and live shows. During the home visits stage, twelve finalists were selected and split into four categories. Each category was mentored by one of the show's four judges. [[Mel B]] mentored the Under 25 Boys,<ref name="Super bootcamp 2013">{{cite episode |title=Season 5, Episode 7: Super bootcamp|series=The X Factor Australia |serieslink=The X Factor (Australian TV series) |network=[[Seven Network]] |airdate=11 August 2013}}</ref> [[Natalie Bassingthwaighte]] had the Under 25 Girls,<ref name="Super bootcamp 2013"/> [[Guy Sebastian]] was given the Over 25s and [[Ronan Keating]] mentored the Groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.throng.com.au/2012/09/the-x-factor-australia-season-four-the-2012-top-twelve-decided/|title=The X Factor Australia – Season Four – The 2012 Top Twelve Decided!|work=Throng|publisher=Throng Media|date=2012-09-12|accessdate=2012-09-12}}</ref> [[Samantha Jade]] was declared the winner, with Sebastian emerging as the winning mentor for the second year in a row.<ref name="finalresults"/>
==Under 25 Boys==
===Josh Brookes=== Josh Brookes was a 20-year-old contestant from [[Perth]], Western Australia,<ref name="boyfactor"/> who auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing [[Eric Clapton]]'s "[[Tears in Heaven]]".<ref name="joshbio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/josh-brookes/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Josh Brookes |work=The X Factor Australia |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdNFB3Q1?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/josh-brookes/ |archivedate=12 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Brookes began singing at age of ten as a way of coping with his [[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]].<ref name="hopefuls"/> During high school, he attended [[Mindarie Senior College]].<ref name="josh&sam">{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Vanessa|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/entertainment/access-all-areas/a/-/14881048/josh-sam-are-x-tra-special/|title=Josh & Sam are X-tra special|work=The West Australian|publisher=Seven West Media Limited|date=2012-09-18|accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> Brookes originally auditioned for the [[The X Factor (Australia season 3)|third season]] of ''The X Factor'' in 2011, but was eliminated during the [[The X Factor (Australia season 3)#Bootcamp|bootcamp]] round to [[Johnny Ruffo]].<ref name="joshbio"/> He stated that his "failure" to make it past bootcamp inspired him to audition again.<ref name="joshbio"/> Brookes cites [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] and [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]] as his musical influences.<ref name="joshbio"/>
On 20 September 2012, the [[Seven Network]] issued a statement saying that Brookes had been disqualified from ''The X Factor'' because he had "behaved in an inappropriate manner" on [[social media]].<ref name="disqualified">{{cite web|last=Pearson|first=Nick|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/entertainment/8536143/x-factor-contestant-josh-brookes-disqualified|title=X Factor contestant Josh Brookes disqualified|work=[[Ninemsn]]|publisher=[[Nine Entertainment Co.]] & [[Microsoft]]|date=2012-09-20|accessdate=2012-09-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921103532/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/entertainment/8536143/x-factor-contestant-josh-brookes-disqualified|archivedate=21 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A [[Twitcam]] video that was later uploaded to [[YouTube]] displayed Brookes and fellow contestant Adil Memon asking teenage girls for "sneaky banana pics", a phrase used by teenagers that means naked images.<ref name="disqualified"/><ref>{{cite news|last2=Vickery|first2=Colin|last1=Byrnes|first1=Holly|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/x-factor-talent-show-contestant-josh-brookes-axed-over-call-for-nude-pics/story-e6frf96f-1226478374488|title=X Factor talent-show contestant Josh Brookes kicked off TV|work=Herald Sun|publisher=The Herald and Weekly Times|date=2012-09-20|accessdate=2012-09-21}}</ref> The Seven Network stated, "After a careful review of the incident, [[FremantleMedia Australia]], producers of the program, together with Channel Seven, made a joint decision to remove him from the competition".<ref name="disqualified"/> During the second live performance show on 25 September 2012, his mentor Mel B announced that Carmelo Munzone, who was eliminated during the [[The X Factor (Australia season 4)#Home visits|home visits]] round, was Brookes' replacement in the live shows.<ref name="return"/>
===Adil Memon=== Adil Memon was an 18-year-old contestant who auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing [[John Mayer]]'s "[[Waiting on the World to Change]]".<ref name="adilbio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/adil-memon/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Adil Memon |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdNyqnh8?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/adil-memon/ |archivedate=12 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Memon comes from a musical family; his mother is an [[Irish people|Irish]] violinist, his father is of [[Pakistani]] descent and plays the drums, and his sister is also a singer. At age of ten, Memon learnt to play the violin, saxophone and guitar. In 2008, he and his family moved from [[England]] to [[Ipswich, Queensland]], Australia.<ref name="xfactorbios"/><ref name="ipswich">{{cite news|last=Lynch|first=Rebecca|url=http://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/story/2012/09/11/gym-goers-back-team-adil/|title=Gym-goers back Team Adil|work=[[Sunshine Coast Daily]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|date=2012-09-11|accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> During high school, Memon attended [[Ipswich Grammar School]].<ref name="ipswich"/> In 2010, Memon and his sister, Maimuna, appeared on ''[[Australia's Got Talent]]''. Before entering ''The X Factor'', he worked at an ice cream shop and was a pool lifeguard. He was also a student at the [[University of Queensland]] and studied Exercise and Nutrition.<ref name="xfactorbios"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Lynch|first=Rebecca|url=http://www.qt.com.au/story/2012/09/08/adil-memon-a-hit-on-x-factor-and-twitter/|title=Adil a hit on X Factor and Twitter|work=[[The Queensland Times]]|publisher=APN News & Media|date=2012-09-08|accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> During the [[The X Factor (Australia series 4)#Super bootcamp|super bootcamp]] round, Memon suffered a nervous breakdown and lost his voice before he was called to perform in front of the judges.<ref name="xfactorbios2"/> He cites John Mayer, [[Emeli Sandé]] and [[Bon Iver]] as his musical influences.<ref name="adilbio"/> Memon landed in the bottom two in week one with [[Samantha Jade]] after receiving the fewest public votes. He was eventually eliminated from the competition after Keating, Sebastian and Bassingthwaighte chose to save Jade.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lewdon |first=Courtney |url=http://www.throng.com.au/2012/09/the-x-factor-australia-season-four-top-12-results-who-will-be-the-first-to-go/ |title=The X Factor Australia – Season Four – Top 12 Results |work=Throng |publisher=Throng Media |date=2012-09-18 |accessdate=2012-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CsIioYfp?url=http://www.throng.com.au/2012/09/the-x-factor-australia-season-four-top-12-results-who-will-be-the-first-to-go/ |archivedate=13 December 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Memon released his debut single "Love I Can Afford" [[Independent music|independently]] on 14 February 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/love-i-can-afford-single/id602823801|title=Love I Can Afford by Adil Memon|publisher=[[iTunes Store]]. [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]|accessdate=2013-07-17}}</ref> His second single "Official" was released on 16 August 2013, through independent label Social Family Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/official-single/id668530376|title=Official by Adil Memon|publisher=iTunes Store. Apple|accessdate=2013-07-17}}</ref> "Official" was written by [[Newton Faulkner]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.air.org.au/features/label-spotlight-social-family-records/|title=Label Spotlight – Social Family Records|publisher=[[Australian Independent Record Labels Association]]|date=2013-07-15|accessdate=2013-07-27}}</ref>
===Carmelo Munzone=== [[File:Carmelo Munzone 2012.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Carmelo Munzone]] Carmelo Munzone was a 23-year-old contestant from [[New South Wales]], who sang [[Maroon 5]]'s "[[Sunday Morning (Maroon 5 song)|Sunday Morning]]" at his audition.<ref name="carmelobio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/carmelo-munzone/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Carmelo Munzone |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ax3lgNda?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/carmelo-munzone/ |archivedate=25 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> He cites Maroon 5, [[OneRepublic]], [[The Script]], [[Jessie J]] and [[Michael Bublé]] as his musical influences.<ref name="carmelobio"/> After Munzone was eliminated during the home visits round, he started auditioning for music university courses.<ref>{{cite news|last=Byrnes|first=Holly|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/carmelo-embraces-x-factor-second-chance/story-e6frf96f-1226481311598|title=Carmelo embraces X Factor second chance|work=Herald Sun|publisher=The Herald and Weekly Times|date=2012-09-25|accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> However, on 21 September 2012, Munzone received a phone call saying that he would be Brookes' replacement in the live shows and had only two days to prepare for his first live performance.<ref name="return">{{cite web|last=Knox|first=David|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2012/09/carmelo-returns-to-the-x-factor.html|title=Carmelo returns to The X Factor|publisher=TV Tonight|date=2012-09-26|accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cartwright|first=Darren|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/entertainment/8538517/munzone-is-recalled-to-x-factor|title=Munzone is recalled to X Factor|work=[[Australian Associated Press]]|publisher=Nine Entertainment Co. & Microsoft|date=2012-09-25|accessdate=2012-09-26}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Jason Owen=== [[File:Jason Owen 2012.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Jason Owen]] {{main article|Jason Owen}} Jason Owen was an 18-year-old contestant from [[Dubbo]], New South Wales,<ref name="boyfactor"/> who sang [[John Denver]]'s "[[Annie's Song]]" at his audition.<ref name="jasonbio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/jason-owen/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Jason Owen |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdOTTopq?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/jason-owen/ |archivedate=13 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Owen grew up in the small town of [[Albert, New South Wales]], which had a population of twelve people. At the age of ten, he joined the school choir but never had proper singing lessons. Before applying for ''The X Factor'', Owen performed in local pubs and clubs and at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. He also worked in his family's fuel business.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> Owen cites [[Dr. Hook & the Medicine Show|Dr. Hook]], [[Smokie (band)|Smokie]], John Denver, [[Celine Dion]], [[Elton John]] and [[Cat Stevens]] as his musical influences.<ref name="jasonbio"/> Following the eliminations of Adil Memon and Carmello Munzone, as well as the disqualification of Josh Brookes, Owen became the last remaining contestant in the Under 25 Boys category. He became the runner-up to Samantha Jade and subsequently received a recording contract with [[Sony Music Australia]].<ref name="finalresults"/>
Owen released his debut single "Make It Last", which would have been his winner's single if he had won ''The X Factor'', on 23 November 2012.<ref name="JasonTheCollective">{{cite news|last=McCabe|first=Kathy|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/x-factor-winner-samantha-jades-single-what-youve-done-to-me-itunes-number-one/story-e6frg6n6-1226521427074|title=X Factor winner Samantha Jade's single What You've Done to Me iTunes number one|work=[[The Australian]]|publisher=[[News Limited]]|date=2012-11-22|accessdate=2012-11-23}}</ref> The single peaked at number 47 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]].<ref name="Jason Owen Discography">{{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Jason+Owen|title=Discography Jason Owen|publisher=Australian Charts Portal. Hung Medien|accessdate=2014-03-16}}</ref> Owen's debut studio album ''Life Is a Highway'' was released on 26 April 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanity.com.au/products/2222736|title=Life is a Highway by Jason Owen|publisher=[[Sanity (music store)|Sanity]]|accessdate=2013-04-13}}</ref> and debuted at number five on the ARIA Albums Chart.<ref name="Jason Owen Discography"/> His second album ''Friday Night'' was released on 6 March 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/friday-night/id953134865|title=Friday Night by Jason Owen|publisher=[[iTunes Store]] (Australia)|accessdate=2015-03-14}}</ref> and debuted at number nine on the ARIA Albums Chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ariacharts.com.au/chart/albums/3419 |title=ARIA Australian Top 50 Albums |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] |date=2015-03-13 |accessdate=2015-03-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402154815/http://ariacharts.com.au/chart/albums/3419 |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df= }}</ref>
==Under 25 Girls==
===Bella Ferraro Rocher=== [[File:Bella Ferraro 2012.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Bella Ferraro]] {{main article|Bella Ferraro}} Bella Ferraro was an 18-year-old contestant from [[Sydney]], New South Wales,<ref name="boyfactor">{{cite web|last=Knox|first=David|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2012/09/boy-factor-on-the-x-factor.html|title=Boy factor on The X Factor|publisher=TV Tonight|date=2012-09-13|accessdate=2012-09-13}}</ref> who sang [[Birdy (musician)|Birdy]]'s version of "[[Skinny Love#Birdy version|Skinny Love]]" at her audition.<ref name="bellabio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/bella-ferraro/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Bella Ferraro |work=[[The X Factor (Australia)]] |publisher=[[Yahoo!7]] |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdLTme6L?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/bella-ferraro/ |archivedate=12 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Ferraro began singing as a child. At the age of five, she became a member of the [[Australian Girls Choir]], who have performed at the annual [[Carols in the Domain]] and during [[Oprah Winfrey]]'s Australian tour. Before applying for ''The X Factor'', Ferraro left school in Year 12 to pursue a music career.<ref name="xfactorbios">{{cite news|last=Byrnes|first=Holly|url=http://www.news.com.au/news/next-stop-the-live-shows-for-x-factors-top-12/story-fnejlvvj-1226473049998|title=X Factor – the live shows begin|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=News Limited|date=2012-09-13|accessdate=2012-09-13}}</ref> She was inspired to audition for the show after seeing the success of [[One Direction]] who were on the [[The X Factor (UK series 7)|UK version]].<ref name="xfactorbios"/><ref name="bellabio"/> Ferraro cites [[Bon Iver]], [[Lykke Li]], [[Crystal Castles (band)|Crystal Castles]], [[Foals (band)|Foals]] and [[Two Door Cinema Club]] as her musical influences.<ref name="bellabio"/> During the [[The X Factor (Australia season 4)#Super bootcamp|super bootcamp]] round, Ferraro forgot the lyrics to the two songs she performed, which were [[Gotye]]'s "[[Somebody That I Used to Know]]" and [[Crowded House]]'s "[[Don't Dream It's Over]]".<ref name="xfactorbios2">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehothits.com/news/34240/x-factor-australia%27s-top-twelve-revealed|title=X Factor Australia's Top Twelve Revealed|work=[[The Hot Hits Live from LA]]|publisher=MCM Entertainment|date=2012-09-13|accessdate=2012-09-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921033203/http://www.thehothits.com/news/34240/x-factor-australia%27s-top-twelve-revealed|archivedate=21 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Following the eliminations of Angel Tupai in week five and Shiane Hawke in week eight, Ferraro became the last remaining contestant in the Under 25 Girls category. After she was eliminated from the competition, Ferraro received a recording contract with [[Sony Music Australia]].
===Shiane Hawke=== [[File:Shiane Hawke 2012.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Shiane Hawke]] Shiane Hawke was a contestant who auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing [[Duffy (singer)|Duffy's]] "[[Mercy (Duffy song)|Mercy]]".<ref name="shianebio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/shiane-hawke/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Shiane Hawke |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdMAHUrz?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/shiane-hawke/ |archivedate=12 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Hawke is an [[Indigenous Australian]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Palin|first=Megan|url=http://www.ntnews.com.au/article/2012/09/27/313900_entertainment.html|title=Darwin darling keeps her place|work=[[Northern Territory News]]|publisher=News Limited|date=2012-09-27|accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> She was born in Sydney, New South Wales and raised in [[Darwin, Northern Territory]].<ref name="xfactorbios"/> Hawke was born with [[Club foot|club feet]] and had them turned around when she was six months old. She had more than 20 operations as a child to fix her feet.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> Hawke taught herself to play the piano and took singing lessons.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> She cites [[Adele]] and [[Aretha Franklin]] as her musical influences.<ref name="shianebio"/> Hawke attended Dripstone Middle School in [[Tiwi, Northern Territory]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Byrnes|first=Holly|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/tv-radio/schoolgirl-shiane-hawke-stars-as-record-audience-watch-channel-sevens-the-x-factor/story-e6frf9ho-1226454917366|title=Schoolgirl Shiane Hawke stars as record audience watch Channel Seven's The X Factor|work=[[Herald Sun]]|publisher=[[The Herald and Weekly Times]]|date=2012-08-21|accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> Before entering ''The X Factor'', she performed at several local talent shows in Darwin, where she received four [[Australian Idol#Touchdowns|touchdowns]] from former ''[[Australian Idol]]'' and ''X Factor'' judge [[Mark Holden]].<ref name="xfactorbios"/> Hawke was the first youngest contestant to make it to the live shows of ''The X Factor Australia''.<ref name="brims">{{cite news|url=http://www.ntnews.com.au/article/2012/09/18/313663_entertainment.html|title=Hawke brims with talent|work=Northern Territory News|publisher=News Limited|date=2012-09-18|accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref>
===Angel Tupai=== Angel Tupai was a 19-year-old contestant from Sydney, New South Wales,<ref name="boyfactor"/> who sang [[Jessie J]]'s "Big White Room" at her audition.<ref name="angelbio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/angel-tupai/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Angel Tupai |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdMao4DJ?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/angel-tupai/ |archivedate=12 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Tupai started singing in church at the age of seven but could not afford proper lessons.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> She attended [[Campbelltown Performing Arts High School]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Priest |first=Evin |url=http://macarthur-chronicle-wollondilly.whereilive.com.au/news/story/macarthur-regions-angel-tupai-favourite-to-win-the-x-factor/ |title=Macarthur region's Angel Tupai favourite to win The X Factor |work=Macarthur Chronicle |publisher=[[NewsLocal]] |date=2012-09-18 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AnMlCVPA?url=http://macarthur-chronicle-wollondilly.whereilive.com.au/news/story/macarthur-regions-angel-tupai-favourite-to-win-the-x-factor/ |archivedate=19 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Tupai received scholarships for her singing and performed at corporate and charity events. She would use the money she made from her gigs to help out her family. She cites [[Whitney Houston]], [[Mariah Carey]], [[Erykah Badu]] and [[Jill Scott]] as her musical influences.<ref name="angelbio"/> Before applying for ''The X Factor'', Tupai was a music teacher and a corporate singer.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> Tupai landed in the bottom two in week three with Justin Standley, but was saved by the judges' votes. She landed in the bottom two again in week five with [[Samantha Jade]] and after the judges decision went to deadlock, she was eliminated.
==Over 25s==
===Samantha Jade=== [[File:Samantha Jade 2012.jpg|thumb|right|140px|[[Samantha Jade]]]] {{main article|Samantha Jade}} Samantha Jade was a 25-year-old contestant from [[Perth]], Western Australia,<ref name="boyfactor"/> who auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing [[The Script]]'s "[[Breakeven (song)|Breakeven]]".<ref name="samanthabio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/samantha-jade/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Samantha Jade |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdP7Zjcq?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/samantha-jade/ |archivedate=13 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2002, Jade's friend sent her [[demo (music)|demo]] to a record producer in [[Los Angeles]], who then decided to send Jade and her family to [[Hollywood]] for a meeting. The following year, they moved to Los Angeles.<ref name="hopefuls">{{cite news|last=McRae|first=Ross|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/entertainment/a/-/entertainment/14839625/perth-pair-x-factor-hopefuls/|title=Perth pair X Factor hopefuls|work=[[The West Australian]]|publisher=[[Seven West Media Limited]]|date=2012-09-13|accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> In 2004, she signed with US record label [[Jive Records]] and began recording a few demo tracks. After three years with the label, Jade's debut album ''My Name is Samantha Jade'' was never released and she was dropped.<ref name="hopefuls"/><ref name="xfactorbios"/><ref name="xfactorbios2"/> After struggling to get a new record deal in the US, Jade moved back to Perth and began working at her father's warehouse in [[Guildford, Western Australia]].<ref name="hopefuls"/><ref name="xfactorbios"/> She later relocated to [[Sydney]], New South Wales, where she became a makeup artist while still gigging.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> Jade cites [[Beyoncé]], [[Robyn]] and [[Mariah Carey]] as her musical influences.<ref name="samanthabio"/> Following the eliminations of Justin Standley in week three and Nathaniel Willemse in week seven, Jade became the last remaining contestant in the Over 25s category. She was announced the winner on 20 November 2012, and received a recording contract with [[Sony Music Australia]] and a [[Nissan Qashqai|Nissan Dualis]] car.<ref name="finalresults"/>
===Justin Standley=== Justin Standley was a 41-year-old contestant from [[Bundaberg]], Queensland,<ref name="xfactorbios"/> who sang [[Elton John]]'s "[[Rocket Man (I Think It's Going to Be a Long, Long Time) (song)|Rocket Man (I Think It's Going to Be a Long, Long Time)]]" at his audition.<ref name="justinbio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/justin-standley/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Justin Standley |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdPcftAQ?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/justin-standley/ |archivedate=13 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Standley lost contact of his three children for 12 years when his relationship with his partner ended. He convinced himself that he did not deserve to see his children because he is [[Homosexuality|gay]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news-mail.com.au/story/2012/08/22/justin-has-x-factor/|title=Justin has the X Factor|work=Bundaberg News Mail|publisher=APN News & Media|date=2012-08-22|accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> Standley found them after his audition was broadcast.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> Before auditioning for ''The X Factor'', Standley was studying to become a teacher at university, worked as a prison choir teacher at the [[Silverwater Women's Correctional Centre]], and performed in pubs and clubs and at the Tamworth Music Festival.<ref name="xfactorbios"/><ref name="justinbio"/> He cites [[The Beatles]], [[Roy Orbison]], [[Slim Dusty]], [[Sara Storer]], [[John Denver]], [[Kasey Chambers]] and [[Joni Mitchell]] as his musical influences.<ref name="justinbio"/>
===Nathaniel Willemse=== {{main article|Nathaniel Willemse}} [[File:Nathaniel Willemse 2012.jpg|thumb|right|140px|[[Nathaniel Willemse]]]] Nathaniel Willemse was a 27-year-old contestant who auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing [[John Mayer]]'s "[[Gravity (John Mayer song)|Gravity]]".<ref name="nathanielbio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/nathaniel-willemse/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Nathaniel Willemse |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdQI8eIs?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/nathaniel-willemse/ |archivedate=13 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Willemse was born in [[South Africa]] and moved to [[Melbourne]], Australia when he was six years-old.<ref name="boyfactor"/><ref name="xfactorbios"/> He previously auditioned for ''[[Australian Idol]]'' at the age of 21 and made it to the top 24 round. Before applying for ''The X Factor'', Willemse was a vocal coach and a wedding singer.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> He cites [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Marvin Gaye]] and [[Justin Timberlake]] as his musical influences.<ref name="nathanielbio"/>
==Groups==
===The Collective=== [[File:The Collective 2013 cropped.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[The Collective (band)|The Collective]]]] {{main article|The Collective (band)}} The Collective<ref>{{cite web|last=Knox|first=David|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2012/09/the-x-factor-6.html|title=X-tra smiles for a hit show|publisher=TV Tonight|date=2012-09-14|accessdate=2012-09-14}}</ref> are a four-member (formerly five-member) boy band consisting of Trent Bell (from [[Brisbane]], Queensland), Jayden Sierra (from [[Camden, New South Wales]]),<ref>{{cite news|last=Goldsworthy |first=Tahnae |url=http://macarthur-chronicle-camden.whereilive.com.au/news/story/camdens-jayden-sierra-has-the-x-factor/ |title=Camden's Jayden Sierra has the X Factor |work=Macarthur Chronicle |publisher=News Community Media |date=2012-09-04 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AvorVvOx?url=http://macarthur-chronicle-camden.whereilive.com.au/news/story/camdens-jayden-sierra-has-the-x-factor/ |archivedate=25 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Julian De Vizio (from [[Adelaide]], South Australia) and Will Singe (from [[Sydney]], New South Wales).<ref name="boyfactor"/> They originally auditioned for ''The X Factor'' as solo contestants, but failed to make the top six of the Under 25 Boys category.<ref name="boybandbio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/the-collective/|title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – The Collective|work=The X Factor (Australia)|publisher=Yahoo!7|date=2012-09-13|accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> They were formed by the judges during the [[The X Factor (Australia season 4)#Super bootcamp|super bootcamp]] round for the Groups category.<ref name="boybandbio"/> The Collective cite [[John Mayer]], [[Chris Brown]], [[Ne-Yo]], [[Justin Bieber]], [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Donny Hathaway]], [[Michael Jackson]] and their fathers as their musical influences.<ref name="boybandbio"/> Following the eliminations of What About Tonight in week two and Fortunate in week six, The Collective became the last remaining act in the Groups category. The Collective placed third in the competition and subsequently received a recording contract with [[Sony Music Australia]].<ref name="finalresults"/><ref name="JasonTheCollective"/> On 26 January 2014, founding member Zach Russell announced on [[Twitter]] that he had left the group.<ref>{{cite news|last=McBryde |first=Emma |url=http://www.cqnews.com.au/news/former-boy-band-member-loses-interest-in-limelight/2157085/ |title=Former boy band member loses interest in limelight |work=[[Central Queensland News]] |publisher=[[APN News & Media]] |date=2014-02-01 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6N6TAyzg0?url=http://www.cqnews.com.au/news/former-boy-band-member-loses-interest-in-limelight/2157085/ |archivedate=3 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Fourtunate=== [[File:Fourtunate 2012.jpg|thumb|180px|left|Fortunate]] Fortunate were a four-member boy band from Sydney, New South Wales, made up of brothers Jaye, Jakiel and Izaia Fuimaono, and best friend Joseph Kalepo.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> They auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing [[Maroon 5]]'s "[[This Love (Maroon 5 song)|This Love]]".<ref name="fourtunatebio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/fourtunate/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – Fourtunate |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdSA2X8t?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/fourtunate/ |archivedate=13 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Fortunate previously auditioned for the [[The X Factor (Australia season 3)|third season]] in 2011, but were eliminated during the [[The X Factor (Australia season 3)#Bootcamp|bootcamp]] round because they lacked experience. This led to them gigging at birthdays, pubes, weddings and festivals.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> Fortunate cite [[Beyoncé]], [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] and [[Jamie Foxx]] as their musical influences.<ref name="fourtunatebio"/> {{clear}}
===What About Tonight=== [[File:What About Tonight 2013.jpg|thumb|right|200px|What About Tonight]] What About Tonight is a four-member (formerly five-member) boy band consisting of Tyrone Georgiadis (from Sydney, New South Wales), Luke Howell (from Sydney, New South Wales), Brock Jays (from [[Wangaratta]], Victoria) and Wade Smith (from [[Byron Bay, New South Wales]]).<ref name="boyfactor"/> They auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing [[We the Kings]]' "Say You Like Me".<ref name="whatabouttonightbio">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/what-about-tonight/ |title=The X-Factor Australia Contestant – What About Tonight |work=The X Factor (Australia) |publisher=Yahoo!7 |date=2012-09-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdSp50uP?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/contestants/what-about-tonight/ |archivedate=13 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> What About Tonight met through [[YouTube]] in early 2012, and began rehearsing over [[Skype]] before coming together a week before their audition.<ref name="xfactorbios"/> They stated that [[One Direction]] inspired them to audition for the show.<ref name="whatabouttonightbio"/> What About Tonight cite One Direction, [[The Wanted]] and Justin Bieber as their musical influences.<ref name="whatabouttonightbio"/> They landed in the bottom two in week two of the live shows with [[Nathaniel Willemse]] and after the judges' decision went to deadlock, it was revealed that What About Tonight received the fewest votes and were eliminated.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lewdon|first=Courtney|url=http://www.throng.com.au/2012/09/the-x-factor-australia-season-four-top-11-results-who-will-be-sent-packing/|title=The X Factor Australia – Season Four – Top 11 Results|work=Throng|publisher=Throng Media|date=2012-09-26|accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref>
After ''The X Factor'', two original members Mitchel Cave and Christian Anthony left the group.<ref name="What About Tonight Interview"/> This opened the door for a nationwide search for a new member and after watching Wade Smith's audition on ''[[The Voice (Australian TV series)|The Voice Australia]]'', he was tracked down and asked to join the group.<ref name="What About Tonight Interview">{{cite news|first=David|last=Giammetta|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/south-west/what-about-tonight-from-x-factor-talk-homelessness/story-fngr8hxh-1226704941170|title=What About Tonight from X Factor talk homelessness|work=Liverpool Leader|publisher=News Limited|date=2013-08-27|accessdate=2014-03-16}}</ref> What About Tonight's debut single "Time of Our Lives" was released on 26 July 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/time-of-our-lives-single/id670993936|title=Time of Our Lives by What About Tonight|publisher=iTunes Store. Apple|accessdate=2013-08-03}}</ref> and peaked at number 25 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=What+About+Tonight|title=Discography What About Tonight|publisher=Australian Charts. '''Louisette Ighilahriz''' (born 22 August 1936) is an Algerian writer and a former member of the [[National Liberation Front (Algeria)|''Front de Libération Nationale'']] (FLN) who came to widespread attention in 2000 with her story of captivity by the French in 1957-62, becoming in the words of the American journalist Adam Shatz "a catalyst of a debate about the legacy of the French-Algerian war".{{cite web | last = Shatz | first = Adam | coauthors = | title= The Torture of Algiers | work = | publisher = ''Algeria-Watch '' | date=21 November 2002| url = http://www.algeria-watch.org/farticle/analyse/shatz_torture.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2016-10-25}} == Biography == Ighilahriz was born in [[Oujda]] to a Berber family and her family moved to [[Algiers]] in 1948. Through born in Morocco, the Ighilhriz family originated from the [[Kabylie]] region of Algeria, whose Berber tribes had been some of the most fiercest opponents of French rule in Algeria. When hearing upon the beginning of the [[Algerian War]] on 1 November 1954, her father, who worked as a baker told her: "It is the end of the humiliation".Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xi. ===FLN=== Strongly anti-French, Ighilahriz joined the FLN under the codename Lila to work as a courier, smuggling information, weapons and bombs across Algiers in bread baked by her father.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xi. On 28 September 1957 while traveling with a FLN party, Ighilahriz was ambushed by the French paratroopers at [[Chébli]], badly wounded and captured.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xi. At the hospital, Ighilahriz was given the "truth drug" Pentohal to make her talk, which failed to achieve its purpose.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xi. ===Military prison=== At which point, Ighilahriz was taken to a military prison at Paradou Hydra where a French Army captain, Jean Graziani, cut her badges, prodded her wounds with a bayonet and then raped her in her words "with all sorts of objects" to make her talk.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xi. For months, Ighilahriz was tortured and raped into attempts to make her reveal what she knew about the FLN before finally breaking down in December 1957, telling her captors everything she knew about the FLN.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 pages xi-xii. During this time, Ighilahriz was not allowed to bath and spent months covered in her own blood, excrement and urine as she was held in a tiny cell.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 233 Ighilahriz remembered: "''Mon urine s’infiltrait sous la bâche du lit de camp, mes excréments se mélangeaient à mes menstrues jusqu’à former une croûte puante''” ("My urine passed through the sheet covering the camp bed, my excrement mixed with my menstrual blood, forming a stinking crust").Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 110. To further degrade her, Ighilahriz was forced to live completely naked during her entire time at the military prison.{{cite web | last = Shatz | first = Adam | coauthors = | title= The Torture of Algiers | work = | publisher = ''Algeria-Watch '' | date=21 November 2002| url = http://www.algeria-watch.org/farticle/analyse/shatz_torture.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2016-10-25}} Ighilahriz recalled:
"I was lying naked, always naked. They would come one, two or three times daily. As soon as I heard the sound of their boots in the hallway, I began to tremble. Then time became endless. The minutes seemed like hours, and the hours like days. The hardest thing was handling the first days, to get used to the pain. Then one would be detached mentally, as if the body began to float.

Massu was brutal, awful. Bigeard was not better, but the worst was Graziani. It’s unspeakable, he was a pervert who took pleasure in torturing. It was not human. I often yelled at him: “You’re not a man if you do not finish me! ” And he answered with a sneer: “Not yet, not yet!” During these three months, I had one goal: to kill myself, but the worst suffering, is to want at all costs to erase oneself and to not find the means."{{cite web | last = | first = | coauthors = | title= Louisette Ighilahriz and the French torture | work = | publisher = ''Algeria'' | date=23 January 2015 | url = http://algeria-dz.tumblr.com/post/108934926694/louisette-ighilahriz-and-the-french-torture | doi = | accessdate = 2016-10-25}}
Ighilahriz stated about Captain Jean Graziani: "''Mais l’essentiel de ses tortures ne s’exerçaient pas à mains nues. Il était toujours armé d’ustensiles pour s’acharner contre mon plâtre''” ("But he did not carry out most of his torture with his bare hands. He was always armed with implements to attack my plaster cast").Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 110. Ighilahriz's family also suffered as she recalled: "They arrested my parents and most of my siblings. My mother has undergone waterboarding for three weeks. One day, they brought before her the youngest of her nine children, my 3 years old little brother, and they hung him."{{cite web | last = | first = | coauthors = | title= Louisette Ighilahriz and the French torture | work = | publisher = ''Algeria'' | date=23 January 2015 | url = http://algeria-dz.tumblr.com/post/108934926694/louisette-ighilahriz-and-the-french-torture | doi = | accessdate = 2016-10-25}} Ighilahriz credited her survival to a doctor whom she knew only as "Richaud", who she called a most gentle and kind man who treated her injuries.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 233 At the time she first met "Richard", Ighilahriz recalled " “''J’étais en train de devenir folle''” ("I was losing my mind"), stating the effects of torture, rape and repeated injections of the "truth drug" Pentohal had pushed her to brink of madness.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 110. "Richaud" told Ighilahriz that she reminded him of his daughter who was about her age, and to whom he was very close.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 109. "Richaud" played something of a surrogate father to Ighilahriz as she remembered him telling her: "''Mon petit, vous êtes bien jeune pour le maquis. Je vous en prie, laissez ça aux autres. Aux hommes, par exemple!''" ("My child, you are too young for the resistance. I beg of you, leave that to others, to men, for example!")Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 109. The scholar Mildred Mortimer wrote that "Richaud" for all his tenderness and compassion towards Ighilahriz ascribed to the traditional French macho viewpoint that war was entirely for men, seeing her involvement with the FLN as something unnatural for a woman, and noted by contrast that Ighilahriz's father had encouraged his daughters to join the FLN.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 109. Mortimer also the irony that through "Richaud" saved Ighilahriz's life that he was a supporter of ''Algérie française'', approving of the goals through not the methods of the French Army in Algeria.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 109. After confessing, Ighilahriz was taken to France, where was held in prisons in [[Baumettes Prison|Baumettes]], [[La Roquette]], [[Amiens]], [[Fresnes Prison|Fresnes]], [[Toulouse]] and [[Bastia]]. In January 1962, Ighilariz escaped from prison, and was hidden by French Communists in Nice. Under the amnesty of May 1962, Ighilahriz was pardoned. Afterwards, Ighilahriz went to university where she obtained a degree in psychology.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 233 In Muslim Algeria, a woman must be a virgin in order to be married, and the subject of rape is strictly taboo, and upon Ighilahriz's return to Algeria, her mother made her promise never to speak of her ordeal lest it shame the family.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 110. After independence, the official language of Algeria became Arabic, but French remains the preferred language for the educated classes in Algeria with Algerian university students still studying all subjects except politics, theology and law in French while even today cabinet meetings in Algeria are conducted in French.{{cite web | last = | first = | title = A battle over language is hampering Algeria’s development | work = | publisher = ''The Economist'' | date= 17 August 2017 | url = https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2017/08/17/a-battle-over-language-is-hampering-algerias-development | doi = | accessdate = 2018-09-30}} One official at the Education Ministry was quoted as saying: "Arabisation was a mistake because it was motivated by this idea of revenge against French colonialism. We shouldn’t confuse the savage, barbaric colonialism of France with the French language, which is a universal vehicle of science and culture.”{{cite web | last = | first = | title = A battle over language is hampering Algeria’s development | work = | publisher = ''The Economist'' | date= 17 August 2017 | url = https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2017/08/17/a-battle-over-language-is-hampering-algerias-development | doi = | accessdate = 2018-09-30}} ===Year 2000=== Ighilahriz's story was unknown until 15 June 2000 when '' Le Monde'' newspaper published an interview conducted by the journalist Florence Beaugé with her.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 233 University-educated, secular, fluent in French and very fond of quoting Victor Hugo, Ighilahriz came across in her interview with Beaugé as more French than Algerian, which helped to make her a more appealing victim to the French.{{cite web | last = Shatz | first = Adam | coauthors = | title= The Torture of Algiers | work = | publisher = ''Algeria-Watch '' | date=21 November 2002| url = http://www.algeria-watch.org/farticle/analyse/shatz_torture.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2016-10-25}} Shatz noted that "What made her interview particularly poignant was that she seemed to be moved less by rage at her jailers than by gratitude to the doctor who saved her."{{cite web | last = Shatz | first = Adam | coauthors = | title= The Torture of Algiers | work = | publisher = ''Algeria-Watch '' | date=21 November 2002| url = http://www.algeria-watch.org/farticle/analyse/shatz_torture.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2016-10-25}} Ighilahriz stated her reason for going forward after remaining silent for decades as she was too ashamed of what had happened to her was she wanted to see "Richaud" one last time to thank him.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 233 ===Interview=== In her interview, Ighilahriz stated that both General [[Marcel Bigeard]] and General [[Jacques Massu]] had been present when she was raped and tortured.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 233 Bigeard stated in an interview that her story was a "tissue of lies" meant to "destroy all that is decent in France" and denied Richaud even existed.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 234 Massu told the French media that he was not present when Ighilahriz was tortured and raped, saying he could not remember her, but expressed "regret" that the paras had engaged in torture and used rape as an interrogation tool, saying that there were things that had happened in Algeria that he wished had never happened.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 234 Massu confirmed the existence of Richaud, saying that Ighilahriz must had been referring to Dr. François Richaud, who had been the doctor stationed at the prison in 1957.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 234 Dr. Richaud had died on 21 September 1997.Cohen, William "The Algerian War, the French State and Official Memory" pages 219-239 from ''Réflexions Historiques'', Vol. 28, No. 2, Summer 2002 page 234 A devout Catholic, Massu had written to Pope Pius XII in February 1957 to complain that the Catholic archbishop of Algiers was not giving his men sufficient spiritual support as they went about the business of torture, and in March 1957 his conscience was greatly eased when the Catholic chaplain attached to his unit told him that God approved of torture as the only way to defeat the FLN, who were all Muslims.Reid, Douglas "Re-Viewing the Battle of Algiers with Germaine Tillion" pages 93-115 from ''History Workshop Journal'', Volume 60, Autumn 2005 page 107. After Ighilarhiz had accused him of torturing her in 2000, General Massu visited his parish priest for confession, and afterwards announced that he changed his mind about torture, saying he now believed it was not necessary to win the Battle of Algiers.Reid, Douglas "Re-Viewing the Battle of Algiers with Germaine Tillion" pages 93-115 from ''History Workshop Journal'', Volume 60, Autumn 2005 page 107. ===Year 2001=== After the interview, Ighilahriz dictated her life story to the French journalist [[Anne Nivat]] which was published in 2001 as ''Algérienne'', becoming a bestseller in France.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xii. Nivat stated about her first impression of Ighilahriz: "''Dès la première seconde où j’ai croisé son regard, j’ai cru en cette femme...Je savais qu’elle parlerait, parce qu’elle avait beaucoup à raconter et souhaitait le raconter. Je n’ai pas été déçue''" (From the moment our eyes met, I believed in this woman. . . . I knew that she would speak, because she had a lot to say and wanted to speak out. I was not disappointed).Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 108. As Algeria is a Muslim nation, the subject of rape is taboo, and Mortimer wrote that it was significant that Ighilahriz's story was published in French rather than her native Berber or Arabic as the story of a Berber woman being raped is unpublishable in Algeria, even today.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 107. At the beginning of ''Algérienne'', Ighilahriz stated that her decision to go forward with her story took place over the opposition of her family, her colleagues and the Algerian government, all of whom felt that the story of a Berber woman being raped was deeply shameful.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 108 & 110. Mortimer wrote through Ighilahriz suffered terribly, the purpose of her story is more to pay tribute to Dr. Richaud rather than to express rage at her torturers and rapists.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 108. A key moment in ''Algérienne'' was when Ighilarhriz and her sister Ouardia visited the grave of Dr. Richaud to place flowers before his tombstone.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 108. On 21 September 2000, the Ighilahriz sisters and Nivat visited the tomb of Dr. Richaud, where the sisters offered him a symbolic cup of coffee as a way of thanks.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 pages 108-109. The ritual performed by the Ighilariz sisters at the grave of Dr. Richaud was not Algerian at all, but rather Mexican as it is common in Mexico on 1 November, the ''Día de Muertos'' ("Day of the Dead"), for families to have picnics on the graves of deceased family members where drinks and food are symbolically offered to the dead.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 pages 108-109. Mortimer wrote the Ighilariz sisters were nominally Muslim, but the two women chose to adopt a barely veiled pagan ritual from Mexico as a way to form a connection with the deceased Dr. Richaud.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 109. Afterwards, the Ighilahriz sisters met with Richaud's daughter to give her their thanks for her father's actions.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 108. On 31 December 2000, Ouardia Ighilahriz returned alone to Richaud's grave to place a plaque reading ''"Où que tu sois, tu seras toujours parmi nous. Louisette''" ("Wherever you are, you will always be among us. Louisette").Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 pages 108-109. Attached to the plaque was a handwritten note with a drawing of a dove carrying an olive branch reading: "''Avec toute ma gratitude.—Louisette''" ("With all my gratitude.–Louisette").Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 pages 109. Mortimer noted that the university-educated and independent-minded Ighilahriz was fluent in French, but chose not to write down her own story, instead dictating it to Nivat, and had to be accompanied by Nivat and her sister to Dr. Richaud's tomb, which for her was evidence of the extraordinary difficult nature of Ighilahriz's experiences.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 108. Mortimer further noted how much emotional support Ighilariz drew from fellow women as her sister Ouardia and Nivat played a key role in helping her confront her past, suggesting the story of ''Algérienne'' is actually the story of three women rather than one.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 110. Mortimer commented that it was striking that it came to dealing with the memory of almost unspeakable physical and sexual abuse that besides for Dr. Richuad, all of the emotional support that Ighilahriz drew upon came from other women.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 110. General [[Maurice Schmitt]] of the French Army accused Ighilahriz of fabricating her entire story in a 2003 essay, making much of the fact that she described Captain Jean Graziani as having green eyes when in fact he had brown eyes.{{cite web |last = Schmitt |first = Maurice |coauthors = |title = Le général Schmitt met à mal le témoignage d’une femme torturée en Algér |publisher = Revue de presss |url = http://kabyle.com/archives/revue-de-presse/berber-news/news/article/le-general-schmitt-met-a-mal-le|website=lemonde.fr |date = July 2003 |accessdate = 2008-05-29 |df = }} Schmitt stated that he served alongside Grazinai in Vietnam, and called him a passionate French patriot from Corsica, whom he described as incapable of committing the acts that Ighilahriz accused him of.{{cite web |last = Schmitt |first = Maurice |coauthors = |title = Le général Schmitt met à mal le témoignage d’une femme torturée en Algér |publisher = Revue de presss |url = http://kabyle.com/archives/revue-de-presse/berber-news/news/article/le-general-schmitt-met-a-mal-le|website=lemonde.fr |date = July 2003 |accessdate = 2008-05-29 |df = }} The Canadian historian Barnett Singer came to Bigeard's defense, writing that Ighilahriz was a terrorist whose account was full of "fabrications" and Bigeard was off hunting the FLN in the ''bled'' at the time she was held by the 10th Parachute Division in late 1957.Singer Barnett ''The Americanization of France: Searching for Happiness after the Algerian War'', Lanham: Rowman & Littlefield, 2013 page 231 More controversy has centered over the fact that in the first edition of ''Algérienne'', Ighilahriz denied being raped, saying “''Il ne pouvait pas non plus me violer, j’étais trop dégueulasse''!" ("He couldn’t think of raping me. I was too disgusting!"), but testified at the civil trial of General Schmitt that she had been raped.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 110. Mortimer defended Ighilariz under the grounds that given her background in Berber culture where it is considered deeply shameful for an unmarried not to be a virgin that it was natural that she would not want to discuss being raped.Mortimer, Mildred "Tortured Bodies, Resilient Souls: Algeria's Women Combatants Depicted by Danièèle Djamila, Amrane-Minne, Louisette Ighilahriz, and Assia Djebar" pages 101-127 from Research in ''African Literatures'', Volume 43, No. 1, Spring 2012 page 110. Rather more unexpectedly, [[Saadi Yacef]], a leading FLN terrorist who is currently a senator in Algeria, attacked Ighilahriz in 2011, claiming she was never a member of the FLN and lied about being raped, stating she is "''excellent dans l'art de faire de la comédie''".{{cite web |last = Akef |first = Amir |coauthors = |title = Une combattante de la guerre d'Algérie victime de propos "ignominieux" |work = |publisher = Le Monde |url = https://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2011/05/06/une-combattante-de-la-guerre-d-algerie-victime-de-propos-ignominieux_1517849_3210.html |date = 6 May 2011 |accessdate = 2008-05-29 |df = }} In response to Schmidt, Ighilariz stated that after the passage of almost 50 years, she may have misremembered small details and the way in which Schmidt obsessively tried to discredit her over small mistakes suggested the French Army on an institutional level was still not willing to admit that it engaged in torture and rape during the Algerian War. In response to Yacef, Ighilariz accused him of breaking under torture when he was captured by the French and stated that as a Berber Muslim man, he was angry at her for breaking the taboo surrounding rape in Berber culture.Rahal, Malika "Fused Together and Torn Apart: Stories and Violence in Contemporary Algeria" pages 118-151 from ''History and Memory'', Volume 24, No. 1, Spring/Summer 2012 page 146. Ighilariz also suggested that Yacef was jealous of the way that her story had come to overshadow his in the popular memory of the Algerian War. Finally, Ighilariz wrote that it was time for the story of the Algerian War to be written in Algeria by professional historians instead of the current situation where the FLN government dictated to historians a version of history that glorified the FLN.Rahal, Malika "Fused Together and Torn Apart: Stories and Violence in Contemporary Algeria" pages 118-151 from ''History and Memory'', Volume 24, No. 1, Spring/Summer 2012 page 146. The British historian [[Martin Thomas (historian)|Martin Thomas]] wrote that Ighilahriz's interview and her book generated a major "media storm" in France in 2000-2001 as her account of physical and sexual abuse while in the custody for three months in late 1957 of the 10th Paratroop Division resonated with the French people, making her into the face of victims of torture in Algeria.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page 462. Thomas further noted that at the same time that ''Algérienne'' was a bestseller, another book about the Algerian War, namely ''Services spéciaux Algérie 1955-1957'' by General [[Paul Aussaresses]], was an even bigger bestseller in France.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xii. Thomas also noted that ''Services spéciaux Algérie 1955-1957'' was translated into English as ''The Battle of the Casbah: Terrorism and Counter-Terrorism in Algeria, 1955-1957'' while ''Algérienne'' still awaits its translation.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xii. Thomas argued many people even today in the West still attach greater value to the lives of Westerners over non-Westerners, which explains why a book by a Frenchman, Aussaresses, describing and justifying torture as a legitimate counter-terrorism tactic in the [[Battle of Algiers (1956–57)|Battle of Algiers]] attracts more attention and better sales than does a book by an Algerian woman describing her experiences of the said torture that Aussaresses ordered.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xii. Along the same lines, Thomas noted in regards to the [[Kenya Emergency]], most people in Britain know of the 32 British settlers killed by the Mau Mau, but very few until recently have been aware of the thousands of Kikuyu killed by British security forces, suggesting there is a certain willful imperial amnesia in both France and Britain.Thomas, Martin ''Fight or Flight: Britain, France, and their Roads from Empire'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014 page xii. ==Endnotes== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ighilahriz, Louisette}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:Algerian torture victims]] [[Category:Algerian revolutionaries]] [[Category:Berber activists]] [[Category:Kabyle people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the National Liberation Front (Algeria)]] [[Category:People from Oujda]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Use British English|date=November 2017}} '''Mary Chudleigh''', Lady Chudleigh (August 1656 – 1710) was an English poet who belonged to an intellectual circle that included [[Mary Astell]], [[Elizabeth Thomas (poet)|Elizabeth Thomas]], [[Judith Drake]], [[Elizabeth Elstob]], [[Lady Mary Wortley Montagu]], and [[John Norris (philosopher)|John Norris]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/astell/ |title=Mary Astell (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy) |website=Plato.stanford.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-01-21}}</ref> In her later years she published a volume of poetry and two volumes of essays, all dealing with feminist themes. Two of her books were published in four editions during the last ten years of her life. Her poetry on the subject of human relationships and reactions has appeared in several anthologies. Her feminist essays are still in print.<ref>Gilbert, Sandra M. and Susan Gubar. "Lady Mary Chudleigh." ''The Norton Anthology of Literature by Women: The Traditions in English''. New York: W. W. Norton, 1996, p. 161.</ref>
==Biography== Mary Lee was born in Winslade, Devon, in August 1656, the daughter of Richard Lee and Mary Sydenham of [[Westminster]].<ref>[[John Lambrick Vivian|Vivian, Lt.Col. J.L.]], (Ed.) The Visitations of the County of Devon: Comprising the Heralds' Visitations of 1531, 1564 & 1620, Exeter, 1895, p. 190, pedigree of Chudleigh</ref> She was baptized in Cyst St. George, Devon parish on 19 August 1656. She was the oldest of three siblings. Her mother's family was the distinguished Sydenham family of Wynfold Eagle, Dorset. Lady Mary's uncle Colonel William Sydenham served on fought in the English Civil War on the side of Parliament; her other uncle, Dr. Thomas Sydenham was well known for his study of epidemic diseases and doctor to [[Anne Conway, Viscountess Conway|Anne Finch]], Vicountess Conway. Her father was a man of property and included "esq" after his name.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Poems and Prose of Lady Mary Chudleigh|last = |first = |publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 1993|isbn = |location = New York|pages = xviii-xvii|editor-last = Ezell|editor-first = Margaret}}</ref>
She married [[Chudleigh Baronets|Sir George Chudleigh, 3rd Baronet]] (died 1718) of [[Ashton, Devon|Ashton]], Devon on 25 March 1674. Her biographers argue as to whether their marriage was happy; her references to marriage as a trap that was psychologically stifling for women suggest that she may have had personal experience with an overbearing husband,<ref>Gilbert, Sandra M. and Susan Gubar. "Lady Mary Chudleigh." ''The Norton Anthology of Literature by Women: The Traditions in English''. New York: W. W. Norton, 1996, p. 161.</ref> but on the other hand, he did allow her to publish several feminist works during his lifetime, and her previously unpublished work was saved carefully by the family after her death.<ref>"[http://www.famouspoetsandpoems.com/poets/lady_mary_chudleigh/biography Lady Mary Chudleigh Biography]." ''Famous Poets and Poems''. 16 December 2006.</ref> They had at least six children, including: *[[Chudleigh baronets|Sir George Chudleigh, 4th Baronet]] (died 1738), eldest son and heir. He married Frances Davie (1697–1748<ref>Dathe of birth per: [[John Lambrick Vivian|Vivian, Lt.Col. J. L.]], (Ed.) The Visitations of the County of Devon: Comprising the Heralds' Visitations of 1531, 1564 & 1620, Exeter, 1895, p. 270, pedigree of Davie; date of death per: [[Tristram Risdon|Risdon, Tristram]] (d. 1640), Survey of Devon, 1811 edition, London, 1811, with 1810 additions, p. 397</ref>), a daughter and co-heiress of [[Davie Baronets|Sir William Davie, 4th Baronet]] (1662–1707) of [[Creedy, Sandford|Creedy House]], Devon, by whom he had four daughters and co-heiresses. *Col. Thomas Chudleigh, 2nd son, of [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]],.<ref>Vivian, p. 190, pedigree of Chudleigh</ref><ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Chudleigh, Mary|first= Jennett|last= Humphreys|volume=10}}</ref><ref>Colman, G. and B. Thornton. ''[http://www.nku.edu/~issues/eminent_ladies/vol1/master_file_vol_1.html#181 Poems by the Most Eminent Ladies of Great Britain and Ireland] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070525154222/http://www.nku.edu/~issues/eminent_ladies/vol1/master_file_vol_1.html |date=2007-05-25 }}''. London, T. Becket and T. Evans, 1773, pp. 180–181. 2003.</ref> whose son was [[Chudleigh Baronets|Sir Thomas Chudleigh, 5th Baronet]] (died 1741) and whose daughter [[Elizabeth Pierrepont, Duchess of Kingston-upon-Hull|Elizabeth Chudleigh]] was wife of [[Augustus John Hervey, 3rd Earl of Bristol]] (1724–1779) and bigamous wife of [[Evelyn Pierrepont, 2nd Duke of Kingston-upon-Hull]] (1771–1773), who built "Chudleigh House" for her. *Eliza Maria Chudleigh. Like most women of her time, she received little in the way of formal education, but read widely <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nku.edu/~issues/eminent_ladies/vol1/master_file_vol_1.html |accessdate=16 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070525154222/http://www.nku.edu/~issues/eminent_ladies/vol1/master_file_vol_1.html |archivedate=25 May 2007 |df= }}</ref> and educated herself in theology, science, and philosophy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.famouspoetsandpoems.com/poets/lady_mary_chudleigh/biography |title=Lady Mary Chudleigh Biography |website=Famouspoetsandpoems.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-21}}</ref> Little else is known about her life except that one of her daughters must have died young, as her grief is mentioned in her letters and some poetry. Mary Chudleigh died on 15 December 1710 from severe rheumatism.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Poems and Prose of Lady Mary Chudleigh|last = |first = |publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 1993|isbn = |location = New York|pages = xxi|editor-last = Ezell|editor-first = Margaret}}</ref>
==Literary works and critical reception== {{Library resources box|by=yes|onlinebooksby=yes|lcheading= Chudleigh, Mary Lee, Lady, 1656-1710}}Critics have tended to read Chudleigh's work biographically; however that began to change by the 1990s as new evidence about her life was uncovered. In her early career she could be described as a Restoration poet of lyrics and satires while in her later career she became a philosophical essayist.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Poems and Prose of Lady, Mary Chudleigh|last = |first = |publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 1990|isbn = 0-19-508360-1|location = New York|pages = xxii-xxiii|editor-last = Ezell|editor-first = Margaret}}</ref>
Heavily influenced by Mary Astell, Lady Mary Chudleigh was one of the first English women to recognize that as a social group, women faced unique challenges. She wrote overtly feminist works and argued strongly for marriage reform and women's education, believing that women should cultivate reason, virtue and stoic integrity despite living in a world full of misogyny. She also wrote significant poems in the retirement tradition combining Platonic and Christian contemplation as a retreat from the vanities of life.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Raising Their Voices British Women Writers. 1650-1750|last = Williamson|first = Marilyn|publisher = Wayne State University Press|year = 1990|isbn = 0-8143-2209-3|location = Detroit|pages = 90–93}}</ref>
Chudleigh is no longer thought to have written the prose work ''The Female Advocate'' (1700), but expressed in her poetry praise for the "ingenious Pen" of the unknown, pseudonymous [[Eugenia (Lady of Quality)|Eugenia]] who wrote it.<ref>Margaret J. M. Ezell: Introduction to ''The Poems and Prose of Mary, Lady Chudleigh'' (1993), p. xxix [https://books.google.hu/books?id=uGQkAe_YuNAC&pg=PR29&lpg=PR29&dq=Eugenia,+the+Lady+of+Quality&source=bl&ots=wLUBWR_a8Y&sig=2-bqrdri75HUKcVseGyZ_gFEdmk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiB7tqKp6HbAhWDDOwKHZO9B94Q6AEIUjAK#v=onepage&q=Eugenia%2C%20the%20Lady%20of%20Quality&f=false Retrieved 25 May 2018.]</ref>
===Individual works=== ''[[The Ladies' Defence]], Or, The Bride-Woman's Counsellor Answer'd : A Poem in a Dialogue Between Sir John Brute, Sir William Loveall, Melissa, and a Parson'' (London, 1701)
This work analyzes marriage from a woman's point of view. Chudleigh, not counting on men to give up their privilege, urges women to avoid marriage and to realize their own self-worth.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Raising Their Voices|last = Williamson|first = Marilyn|publisher = Wayne State University Press|year = 1990|isbn = 0-8143-2209-3|location = Detroit|page = 95}}</ref>
''[[Poems on Several Occasions (Lady Mary Chudleigh)|Poems on Several Occasions]]'' (London, 1703)
By dedicating this work to Queen Anne, Chudleigh was seeking her protection from potential backlash.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Raising Their Voices: British Women Writers 1650-1750|last = Williamson|first = Marilyn|publisher = Wayne State University Press|year = 1990|isbn = 0-8143-2209-3|location = Detroit|page = 90}}</ref>
''[[Essays Upon Several Subjects]]'' (London, 1710)
Chudleigh urges women not to be concerned with wealth, status, interest or ambition in this collection.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Raising Their Voices: British Women Writers, 1650-1750|last = Williamson|first = Marilyn|publisher = Wayne State University Press|year = 1990|isbn = 0-8143-2209-3|location = Detroit|page = 95}}</ref>
===Collected works=== * ''The Poems and Prose of Mary, Lady Chudleigh'', ed. Margaret J.M. Ezell (New York: Oxford University Press, 1993).<ref name="BOL">{{cite web|url=http://andromeda.rutgers.edu/~jlynch/C18/biblio/chudleigh.html |title=Chudleigh Bibliography (Ezell) |website=Andromeda.rutgers.edu |date=1999-07-09 |accessdate=2016-01-21}}</ref>
===Correspondence=== * [[Elizabeth Thomas (poet)|Elizabeth Thomas]], ''Pylades and Corinna'' (London, 1731). * ''The Poetical Works of Philip Late Duke of Wharton'' (London, 1731). * British Library MSS Stowe 223, f. 398. * British Library MSS Stowe 224, f. 1.<ref name="BOL"/>
==Further information==
===Biographies=== * George Ballard, ''Memoirs of Several Ladies of Great Britain who have been Celebrated for their Writings or Skill in the Learned Languages, Arts and Sciences'', ed. Ruth Perry (Detroit: Wayne State Univ. Press, 1985).<ref name="BOL"/>
===Anthologies=== * ''[[Norton Anthology of Literature by Women]]: The Traditions in English'', [[Sandra Gilbert]] and [[Susan Gubar]], eds. * ''The First Feminists: British Women Writers'', Moira Fergusson, ed., (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1985). * ''Eighteenth-Century Women Poets: An Oxford Anthology'', Roger Lonsdale, ed. (New York: Oxford University Press, 1989). * ''British Literature: An Anthology'', Robert DeMaria, Jr., ed. (London: Blackwell, 1996).<ref name="BOL"/>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== *[http://literaryplaces.co.uk/?p=1388/ Mary Chudleigh at Literary Places.co.uk] *[http://essays.quotidiana.org/chudleigh/ Essays by Mary Chudleigh at Quotidiana.org] * {{Librivox author |id=3170}}
{{Authority control}}

[[MANS Entertainment]] (2018-present) | associated_acts = {{ill|Duo Maia|lt=MAIA|id|MAIA (grup musik)}} | current_members = MAIA }} '''Dita''' (formerly known as '''Mey Chan''', born 14 May 1986, [[Malang]]) is an [[Indonesia]]n female singer who is a former member of the band {{ill|Duo Maia|lt=MAIA|id|MAIA (grup musik)}} . ==Biography== ===Career=== Before she joined MAIA she had been in the Komet 14, Infinity, Dimensi Baru and Punk Romance bands.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} ===Duo MAIA=== At 2008, Chan passed an audition and was selected by [[Maia Estianty]] to join her.[http://www.kapanlagi.com/h/0000208121.html Gabung Maia, Mey Chan Sempat Ngeri], kapanlagi.com; accessed 21 January 2008. But finally Mey joined Maia and released the album titled ''Duo Maia, Maia & Friends'' (2008).[http://www.kapanlagi.com/h/0000208076.html Rilis Single Baru, Maia Kubur Masa Lalu], kapanlagi.com; accessed on January 21, 2008 ==Discography== ===MAIA=== * ''Maia & Friends'' (2008) * ''Sang Juara'' (2009) * ''Maia Pasto with the Stars'' (2015) === Singles === * Jangan Selingkuh * Gengsi Setengah Mati * Korban Cinta * Setia (2018; with real name Dita) ==Filmography== * ''XXL-Double Extra Large'' (2009) ==Television shows== * [[The Remix (TV series)|The Remix]] ([[NET.]]) (2015) - with NSG in Rarasurya * [[Just Duet]] ([[NET.]]) (2016) as a judge ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Instagram|ditaofficial.id}} * {{kapanlagi|d|dita}} * [http://www.duniamaia.com/biography/index/meychan Profile on MAIA's official website] {{id}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chan, Mey}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:Indonesian-language singers]] [[Category:Indonesian female singers]] [[Category:Indonesian pop singers]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Indonesian Christians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Musicians from East Java]] [[Category:People from Malang]] [[Category:Javanese people]] {{Indonesia-singer-stub}}

T. McFarland]] | predecessor = [[Susan Rice]] | president = [[Donald Trump]] | successor = [[H. R. McMaster]] | signature = Michael Flynn Signature.png | office1 = [[Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency]] | predecessor1 = [[Ronald L. Burgess, Jr.|Ronald Burgess]] | president1 = [[Barack Obama]] | successor1 = [[David Shedd]] (Acting) | birth_name = Michael Thomas Flynn | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|12|5}} | birth_place = [[Fort Meade, Maryland]], U.S. | spouse = Lori Andrade | children = 2 | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] | website = {{URL|michaeltflynn.com|Official website}} | allegiance = {{flag|United States}} | branch = {{army|United States}} | serviceyears = 1981–2014 | rank = [[File:US-O9 insignia.svg|35px]] [[Lieutenant General (United States)|Lieutenant General]] | unit = {{plainlist| * [[Defense Intelligence Agency]] * [[Joint Functional Component Command for Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance]] }} | battles = {{plainlist| * [[Invasion of Grenada|Operation Urgent Fury]] * [[Operation Uphold Democracy]] * [[War in Afghanistan (2001–14)|Operation Enduring Freedom]] * [[Operation Iraqi Freedom]] }} | term_start = January 20, 2017 | term_end = February 13, 2017 | term_start1 = July 24, 2012 | term_end1 = August 7, 2014 | education = {{plainlist| * [[University of Rhode Island|University of Rhode Island, Kingston]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]]) * [[Golden Gate University]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]]) * [[United States Army Command and General Staff College]] ([[Masters of Military Art and Science|MMAS]]) * [[Naval War College]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]]) }} | mawards = {{plainlist| * [[Defense Distinguished Service Medal]] * [[Defense Superior Service Medal]] (4) * [[Legion of Merit]] (2) * [[Bronze Star Medal]] (4) * [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]] (6) * [[Joint Service Commendation Medal]] * [[Army Commendation Medal]] (5) }} }}
'''Michael Thomas Flynn''' (born December 1958) is a retired [[United States Army]] [[Lieutenant General (United States)|Lieutenant General]] who served in the U.S. Army for 33 years, from 1981 until 2014. In January 2017 he briefly served as [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] to [[U.S. President]] [[Donald Trump]].
