In December 2017 he pleaded guilty to one count of lying to the [[FBI]] (a [[felony]]) about contacts he had with the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]] during [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump|Trump's presidential transition]].
Flynn's military career included a key role in shaping U.S. counterterrorism strategy and dismantling insurgent networks in Afghanistan and Iraq, and he was given numerous [[combat arms]], conventional, and [[special operations]] senior intelligence assignments.<ref>Whitlock, Craig and Miller, Greg. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trumps-national-security-adviser-shared-secrets-without-permission-files-show/2016/12/13/72669740-c146-11e6-9578-0054287507db_story.html "Trump’s national security adviser shared secrets without permission, files show"], [[Washington Post]] (December 14, 2016).</ref><ref name="ABCNews">{{cite news |last1=Abramson|first1=Alana|title=Michael Flynn: Everything You Need to Know|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/michael-flynn/story?id=40443952|date=July 18, 2016|website=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=September 27, 2016}}</ref><ref name="retirement">{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=122868|title=Rogers Lauds Retiring Defense Intelligence Agency Chief|date=August 7, 2014|first=Claudette|last=Roulo|publisher=DoD News, Defense Media Activity}}</ref>
He was appointed by President [[Barack Obama]] as the eighteenth [[director of the Defense Intelligence Agency]], serving from July 2012 until his forced retirement from the military in August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/head-of-pentagon-intelligence-agency-forced-out-officials-say/2014/04/30/ec15a366-d09d-11e3-9e25-188ebe1fa93b_story.html|title=Head of Pentagon intelligence agency ousted, officials say|first1=Greg|last1=Miller|first2=Adam|last2=Goldman|date=April 30, 2014|publisher=|accessdate=May 19, 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/10/how-mike-flynn-became-americas-angriest-general-214362|title=How Mike Flynn Became America's Angriest General|publisher=|accessdate=May 19, 2018}}</ref><ref name=DIAgency>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140803211025/http://www.dia.mil/About/Leadership/ArticleView/tabid/3982/Article/6952/lieutenant-general-michael-t-flynn-usa.aspx "Lieutenant General Michael T. Flynn, USA: Director"]. [[Defense Intelligence Agency]]. Retrieved February 14, 2017.</ref> ''The New York Times'' reported on May 18, 2018, that a longtime FBI/CIA informant had met Flynn at an intelligence seminar in Britain six months earlier and became alarmed by Flynn's closeness to a Russian woman there; this concern prompted another individual to alert American authorities that Flynn may have been compromised by Russian intelligence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/18/us/politics/trump-fbi-informant-russia-investigation.html|title=F.B.I. Used Informant to Investigate Russia Ties to Campaign, Not to Spy, as Trump Claims|date=May 18, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=May 19, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
After leaving the military, he established Flynn Intel Group, which has provided intelligence services for businesses and governments, including ones in Turkey.<ref name="McBride">{{Cite news|url=http://heavy.com/news/2016/07/general-michael-flynn-michael-t-flynn-vice-president-donald-trump-runningmate-short-list-republican-national-convention-lori-wife-children-family-isis-obama-clinton-radical-islam-muslim-rational-iraq/|title=Michael Flynn: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|last=McBride|first=Jessica|date=July 10, 2016 |publisher=Heavy.com|access-date=November 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>Baker, Peter and Rosenberg, Matthew. [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/10/us/politics/michael-flynn-turkey.html "Michael Flynn Was Paid to Represent Turkey’s Interests During Trump Campaign"], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (March 10, 2017).</ref>
Flynn briefly served as the [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] for President [[Donald Trump]], from January 20 to February 13, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/13/us/politics/donald-trump-national-security-adviser-michael-flynn.html|title=Michael Flynn Resigns as National Security Adviser|last=Apuzzo|first=Maggie Haberman, Matthew Rosenberg, Matt |date=February 13, 2017 |newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=February 14, 2017|last2=Thrush|first2=Glenn|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> He resigned after information surfaced that he had misled the [[FBI]] and Vice President [[Mike Pence]] about the nature and content of his communications with the Russian ambassador to the U.S., [[Sergey Kislyak]].<ref>Greg Miller, Adam Entous and Ellen Nakashima, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/national-security-adviser-flynn-discussed-sanctions-with-russian-ambassador-despite-denials-officials-say/2017/02/09/f85b29d6-ee11-11e6-b4ff-ac2cf509efe5_story.html National security adviser Flynn discussed sanctions with Russian ambassador, despite denials, officials say], ''Washington Post'' (February 9, 2017).</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Pramuk|first1=Jacob|title=Trump: I fired Flynn because of what he told Pence|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/16/trump-no-i-didnt-tell-flynn-to-talk-about-sanctions-with-russia.html|date=February 16, 2016 |website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref> Flynn's tenure of just 24 days was the shortest in the office's history.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://quantitativepeace.com/blog/2017/02/on-michael-flynns-tenure-as-national-security-advisor.html|title=On Michael Flynn's Tenure as National Security Advisor|date=February 14, 2017|newspaper=The Quantitative Peace|access-date=February 14, 2017}}</ref><ref name="HawkinsShortest">Derek Hawkins, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/02/14/flynn-sets-record-with-only-24-days-as-nsc-chief-the-average-tenure-is-about-2-6-years/ Flynn sets record with only 24 days as national security advisor. The average tenure is about 2.6 years.], ''Washington Post'' (February 14, 2017).</ref>
On April 27, 2017, the Pentagon inspector general announced an investigation into whether Flynn had accepted money from foreign governments without the required approval.<ref name="inspector">{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-flynn-idUSKBN17T26Q|title=Pentagon probes Trump's ex-adviser Flynn over foreign payments|last=Landay|first=Jonathan|date=April 27, 2017|work=Reuters}}</ref> Flynn initially refused to hand over [[subpoena]]ed documents to the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]], pleading the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]] against self-incrimination, but a compromise with the committee was worked out.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/22/529498045/flynn-to-take-the-5th-refuses-to-turn-over-documents-to-senate-panel|title=Flynn Takes The 5th, Refuses To Turn Over Documents To Senate Panel|work=[[NPR]] |first1=Brian |last1=Naylor|first2=Mary Louise|last2=Kelly|date=May 22, 2017|accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref><ref name="cbsnews.com">[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/flynn-turns-over-documents-to-senate-panel-probing-russia-trump "Flynn turns over documents to Senate panel probing Russia, Trump"], [[CBS News]] (June 7, 2017).</ref> On December 1, 2017, Flynn appeared in federal court to formalize a deal with Special Counsel [[Robert Mueller]] to plead guilty to a single felony count of "willfully and knowingly" [[Making false statements|making "false, fictitious and fraudulent statements"]] to the FBI.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/12/01/politics/michael-flynn-charged/index.html|title=Flynn charged with one count of making false statement|first=Jeremy|last=Herb|publisher=''[[CNN]]''|date=December 1, 2017}}</ref> He confirmed his intention to cooperate with the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|Special Counsel's investigation]].
==Early life== Michael Thomas Flynn was born and raised in [[Middletown, Rhode Island]],<ref name=ABCNews/> as one of nine children<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.earnthenecklace.com/lori-flynn-michael-flynn-wife-wiki-age-family-children-pics/|title=Lori Flynn: 3 Facts to Know about Michael Flynn's Wife|publisher=Earn The Necklace|date=31 March 2017|author=John, Caroline}}</ref> to Helen Frances (Andrews), who worked in real estate, and Charles Francis Flynn, a small-town banker.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.uri.edu/quadangles/saluting-a-family-legacy/|title=Saluting A Family Legacy|last=|first=|date=August 13, 2009|website=Quadrangles Online|publisher=[[University of Rhode Island]]|access-date=July 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newportri.com/features/personalities/brothers-in-arms/article_22da3766-e665-11e0-bbcb-001cc4c03286.html|title=Brothers in arms|last=Gillis|first=James J.|date=September 24, 2011|newspaper=The Newport Daily News|access-date=July 9, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170331212242/http://www.newportri.com/features/personalities/brothers-in-arms/article_22da3766-e665-11e0-bbcb-001cc4c03286.html|archive-date=March 31, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://statewidemls.com/NewsAndEvents/RealtorPassings.asp |title=Recent Losses in the REALTOR Family |website=statewidemls.com |access-date=July 9, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160710141805/http://statewidemls.com/NewsAndEvents/RealtorPassings.asp |archivedate=July 10, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/16220615/|title=Miss Helen F. Andrews Weds Charles F. Flynn|last=|first=|date=May 10, 1946|access-date=July 9, 2016|via=Newspapers.com|newspaper=Newport Mercury}}</ref> Both of his parents are of Irish descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thenational.ae/hubris-the-fall-of-general-mike-flynn-1.680608|date=2 December 2017|title=Hubris: the fall of General Mike Flynn|publisher=The National|author=Gornall, Jonathan; Jacobson, Seth}}</ref>
Michael Flynn graduated from the [[University of Rhode Island]] with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[management science]] in 1981 and was a Distinguished Military Graduate of the [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]]. He also earned a [[Master of Business Administration]] in [[Telecommunication]]s from [[Golden Gate University]], a Master of Military Art and Science from the [[United States Army Command and General Staff College]], and a [[Master of Arts]] in National Security and Strategic Studies from the [[Naval War College]].<ref name=DIAgency/>
Flynn is a graduate of the Military Intelligence Officer Basic Course, [[Ranger School]], Military Intelligence Officer Advanced Course, [[United States Army Command and General Staff College|Army Command and General Staff College]], the [[School of Advanced Military Studies]], and [[Naval War College]].<ref name=DIAgency/>
==Military career== ===U.S. Army=== [[File:260554 Stanley McChrystal, Michael T. Flynn in Afghanistan 2010.jpg|thumb|left|General [[Stanley McChrystal]] and Flynn in Afghanistan, 2010]] Flynn was commissioned in the U.S. Army as a second lieutenant in military intelligence in 1981.<ref name=DIAgency/> His military assignments included multiple tours at [[Fort Bragg]], North Carolina, with the [[82d Airborne Division|82nd Airborne Division]], [[XVIII Airborne Corps]], and Joint Special Operations Command, where he deployed for the [[invasion of Grenada]] and [[Operation Uphold Democracy]] in [[Haiti]].<ref>Gal Perl Finkel, [http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/President-elect-Trump-the-West-Wing-lesson-472721 President-elect Trump – the 'West Wing' lesson], ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', November 15, 2016.</ref> He also served with the [[25th Infantry Division (United States)|25th Infantry Division]] at [[Schofield Barracks]], [[Hawaii]], at the [[Fort Polk|Joint Readiness Training Center at Fort Polk]], [[Louisiana]], and the [[United States Army Intelligence Center|Army Intelligence Center]] at [[Fort Huachuca]], [[Arizona]].<ref name=DIAgency/>
Flynn served as the assistant chief of staff, [[Staff (military)#Continental Staff System|G2]], XVIII Airborne Corps at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, from June 2001 and the director of intelligence at the [[Combined Joint Task Force 82|Joint Task Force 180]] in Afghanistan until July 2002. He commanded the [[111th Military Intelligence Brigade]] from June 2002 to June 2004<ref name=DIAgency/> and was the director of intelligence for [[Joint Special Operations Command]] from July 2004 to June 2007, with service in [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]] ([[Operation Enduring Freedom]]) and the [[Iraq War]] (Operation Iraqi Freedom). He served as the director of intelligence of the [[United States Central Command]] from June 2007 to July 2008, as the director of intelligence of the Joint Staff from July 2008 to June 2009, then the director of intelligence of the [[International Security Assistance Force]] in Afghanistan from June 2009 to October 2010.<ref name=DIAgency/><ref name="intelligence">{{Cite news |first=Mark |last=Mardell |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/markmardell/2010/01/a_damning_view_of_us_intellige.html |title=A damning view of US intelligence in Afghanistan |date=January 5, 2010 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
====Defense Intelligence Agency==== [[File:Defense.gov photo essay 120724-D-BW835-223.jpg|right|thumb|Flynn speaks during the change of directorship for the Defense Intelligence Agency on Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling in Washington, D.C.]] [[File:From left, Deanie Dempsey; Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff U.S. Army Gen. Martin E. Dempsey; Stephanie Carter; Deputy Secretary of Defense Ash Carter; Lori Flynn; and Army Gen. Michael T. Flynn 130611-D-HU462-039.jpg|thumb|Flynn with [[Martin Dempsey]] and [[Ashton Carter]], June 11, 2013]] In September 2011, Flynn was promoted to Lieutenant General and assigned as [[Director of National Intelligence|assistant director of national intelligence]] in the [[Office of the Director of National Intelligence]]. On April 17, 2012, President [[Barack Obama]] nominated Flynn to be the 18th [[director of the Defense Intelligence Agency]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Flynn to head DIA; more general moves announced |url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2012/04/army-flynn-dia-general-moves-announced-041712w/|work=Army Times|accessdate=April 18, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/2012/04/michael-flynn-dia/ |date=April 17, 2012 |publisher=Wired |title=Military Intelligence Gadfly Will Lead All Military Intelligence |first=Spencer |last=Ackerman}}</ref> Flynn took command of the DIA in July 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Panetta: Under Burgess, DIA Evolved Into Global Agency|url=http://archive.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=117250|accessdate=April 9, 2017}}</ref> He simultaneously became commander of the [[Joint Functional Component Command for Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance]], and chair of the [[Military Intelligence Board]].
In October 2012, Flynn announced plans to release his paper "VISION2020: Accelerating Change Through Integration", a look at changes he believes are necessary for the DIA in the future.<ref>{{cite web|title=DIA maps out new structure to address 'persistent conflict|url=http://defensesystems.com/articles/2012/10/10/geoint-flynn-dia.aspx|publisher=Defense Systems|accessdate=October 17, 2012|first=Charles |last=Hoskinson|date=October 10, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Government Executive">[[Government Executive]], [http://www.govexec.com/defense/2012/11/intelligence-community-must-adapt-era-vast-data-study-says/59886/ Intelligence community must adapt to era of vast data, study says] (November 2012).</ref>
In June 2013, Michael Flynn became the first U.S. officer to be allowed inside the [[GRU|Russian military intelligence (GRU)]] headquarters in [[Moscow]], where he arrived at the invitation of the GRU chief Gen [[Igor Sergun]].<ref name="zwack">Peter Zwack. [http://www.defenseone.com/ideas/2016/02/death-gru-commander/125567/ Death of the GRU Commander] Defense One, 1 February 2016.</ref><ref name="guardflynn">[https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/31/michael-flynn-new-evidence-spy-chiefs-had-concerns-about-russian-ties Michael Flynn: new evidence spy chiefs had concerns about Russian ties: US and UK officials were troubled by Moscow contacts and encounter with woman linked to Russian spy agency records] The Guardian, 31 March 2017.</ref> His follow-up trip to visit the GRU HQ as Director of DIA was not allowed.<ref name="guardflynn" />
====Retirement from the military==== On April 30, 2014, Flynn announced his retirement effective later that year, about a year earlier than he had been scheduled to leave his position. He was reportedly effectively forced out of the DIA after clashing with superiors over his allegedly chaotic management style and vision for the agency.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Top 2 Pentagon intelligence officials abruptly quit|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/top-2-pentagon-intelligence-officials-quitting-203851795--politics.html|publisher=Yahoo News|accessdate=July 10, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/head-of-pentagon-intelligence-agency-forced-out-officials-say/2014/04/30/ec15a366-d09d-11e3-9e25-188ebe1fa93b_story.html |title=Head of Pentagon intelligence agency forced out, officials say |first=Greg |last=Miller |first2=Adam |last2=Goldman |date= April 30, 2014 |accessdate=July 9, 2016|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2016/09/15/michael-flynn-trumps-military-adviser-says-colin-powells-emails-include-really-mean-things/|title=Michael Flynn, Trump's military adviser, says Colin Powell's emails include 'really mean things'|newspaper=The Washington Post|access-date=November 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://theintercept.com/2016/07/13/an-interview-with-lt-gen-michael-flynn/|title=An Interview With Michael T. Flynn, the Ex-Pentagon Spy Who Supports Donald Trump|last=Devereaux|first=Ryan|date=|publisher=The Intercept |access-date=November 19, 2016}}</ref> In a private e-mail that was leaked online, [[Colin Powell]] said that he had heard in the DIA (apparently from later DIA director [[Vincent R. Stewart]]) that Flynn was fired because he was "abusive with staff, didn't listen, worked against policy, bad management, etc."<ref name="auto"/> According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', Flynn exhibited a loose relationship with the truth, leading his subordinates to refer to Flynn's repeated dubious assertions as "Flynn facts".<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/18/us/politics/michael-flynn-national-security-adviser-donald-trump.html|title=Trump Is Said to Offer National Security Post to Michael Flynn, Retired General|last=Rosenberg|first=Matthew|date=November 17, 2016|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=November 18, 2016}}</ref>
According to what Flynn had stated in one final interview as DIA director, he felt like a lone voice in thinking that the United States was less safe from the threat of [[Islamic terrorism]] in 2014 than it was prior to the [[9/11 attacks]]; he went on to believe that he was pressed into retirement for questioning the Obama administration's public narrative that [[Al Qaeda]] was close to defeat.<ref name="Kitfield">James Kitfield, [http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/10/how-mike-flynn-became-americas-angriest-general-214362 How Mike Flynn Became America's Angriest General], ''Politico Magazine'' (October 2016).</ref> Journalist [[Seymour Hersh]] wrote that "Flynn confirmed [to Hersh] that his agency had sent a constant stream of classified warnings ... about the dire consequences of toppling [Syrian President] [[Bashar al-Assad|Assad]]." Flynn recounted that his agency was producing intelligence reports indicating that radical Islamists were the main force in the Syrian insurgency and "that Turkey was looking the other way when it came to the growth of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] inside Syria". According to Flynn, these reports "got enormous pushback from the Obama administration," who he felt "did not want to hear the truth". According to former DIA official [[W. Patrick Lang]]: "Flynn incurred the wrath of the White House by insisting on telling the truth about Syria ... they shoved him out. He wouldn't shut up."<ref name="Hersh">{{Cite news|authorlink=Seymour Hersh|last=Hersh|first=Seymour|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v38/n01/seymour-m-hersh/military-to-military|title=Military to Military|work=[[London Review of Books]]|volume=38|issue=1|date=January 7, 2016|accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref> In an interview with Al Jazeera, Flynn criticized the Obama administration for its delay in supporting the opposition in Syria, thereby allowing for the growth of [[Al-Nusra]] and other extremist forces: "when you don't get in and help somebody, they're gonna find other means to achieve their goals" and that "we should have done more earlier on in this effort, you know, than we did."<ref name=":3" />
Flynn retired from the U.S. Army with 33 years of service on August 7, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ccjsymposium.com/speaker/lt-gen-mike-flynn/|title=Lt. Gen. Mike Flynn |publisher=CCJ Symposium}}</ref>
==Post-retirement==
===Consulting firm=== Flynn, with his son Michael G. Flynn, ran the [[Flynn Intel Group Inc]], which provided intelligence services for businesses and governments before closing in 2016.<ref name="NYT2">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/18/us/politics/michael-flynn-intel-group-trump.html |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|title=How Michael Flynn's Disdain for Limits Led to a Legal Quagmire|date=June 18, 2017|first=Nicholas|last=Confessore|first2=Matthew|last2=Rosenberg |first3=Danny |last3=Hakim}}</ref><ref name="McBride"/> The company was founded in the fall of 2014, and restarted in June 2015 as a [[Delaware General Corporation Law|Delaware company]].<ref name="NYT2"/>
Flynn was paid over $65,000 by companies connected to Russia in 2015, including $11,250 from both [[Volga-Dnepr Airlines]] and the U.S. subsidiary of [[Kaspersky Lab]].<ref name="NYT2"/><ref name=NYT23may17>{{cite news|last1=[[Mark Mazzetti]]|last2=[[Matthew Rosenberg]]|title=Michael Flynn Misled Pentagon About Russia Ties, Letter Says|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/22/us/politics/michael-flynn-fifth-amendment-russia-senate.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 23, 2017|page=A1}}</ref> Other clients included [[Palo Alto Networks]], [[Francisco Partners]], Brainwave Science and [[Adobe Systems]].<ref name="NYT2"/>
While working as a consultant Flynn served on the board of several organizations, including GreenZone Systems, Patriot Capital, Brainwave, Drone Aviation and OSY Technologies.<ref name="CTV"/><ref name="NYT2"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-12-23/trump-aide-partnered-with-firm-run-by-man-with-alleged-kgb-ties|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |quote=Brainwave is seeking to develop a market for its innovative—but broadly disputed—technology called "brain fingerprinting" which tries to assess an interrogation subject's honesty through a brain scan. Flynn was brought onto the company's board of advisers to help sell the product to defense and law enforcement agencies, Brainwave President Krishna Ika said in an interview. |title=Trump Aide Partnered With Firm Run by Man With Alleged KGB Ties|date=December 23, 2016 |first=David|last=Kocieniwski|first2=Peter|last2=Robinson|access-date=June 18, 2017}}</ref> Subsidiaries of the Flynn Intel Group included FIG Cyber Inc, headed by Timothy Newberry, and FIG Aviation.<ref name="CTV">{{cite news |publisher=[[CTV News]]|title=Michael Flynn, fired once by a president, now resigns to another |first=Stephen|last=Braun|first2=Robert|last2=Burns|date=February 14, 2017|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/michael-flynn-fired-once-by-a-president-now-resigns-to-another-1.3284392}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/the-mystery-behind-a-flynn-associates-quiet-work-for-the-trump-campaign/2017/05/04/fc86980e-3044-11e7-9534-00e4656c22aa_story.html?tid=ss_tw|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|title=The mystery behind a Flynn associate's quiet work for the Trump campaign|date=May 4, 2017 |first=Matea|last=Gold}}</ref>
In July 2018, the consulting firm Stonington Global LLC announced that Flynn was joining the firm as its director of global strategy, though Flynn's attorneys disputed that there had ever been a partnership several hours later.<ref name="stonington">{{cite news |publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' |title=Mike Flynn’s Lawyers Say He Is No Longer Joining Consulting Firm |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mike-flynn-lawyers-say-he-is-no-longer-joining-consulting-firm-1531245600 |date=July 10, 2018 |first=Julie |last=Bykowicz |first2=Del Quentin |last2=Wilber |first3=Aruna |last3=Viswanatha |archive-url=https://archive.today/20180711001909/https://www.wsj.com/articles/mike-flynn-lawyers-say-he-is-no-longer-joining-consulting-firm-1531245600 |archive-date=July 11, 2018 |access-date=July 11, 2018 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
====Foreign agent==== In July 2016, Flynn spoke at a meeting of [[ACT! for America]] at a point when the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt]] against [[Turkey|Turkish]] President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] was still underway. He spoke favorably of the coup participants, saying that Erdoğan had been moving Turkey away from secularism and towards Islamism and that participants in the coup wanted Turkey to be and to be seen as a secular nation—a goal "worth clapping for."<ref name="ACTspeech">{{cite AV media|title=Act! Cleveland Meeting: General Michael Flynn|medium=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p1mG4aVFEiI|accessdate=March 11, 2017|time=13:15|date=July 15, 2016}}</ref>
By the end of September 2016, Flynn's consulting company was hired by Inovo BV, a company owned by Kamil Ekim Alptekin, the Chair of the Turkish-American Business Council, which is an arm of the Foreign Economic Relations Board of Turkey (DEIK).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/11/donald-trump-turkey-lobbying-231354|title=Trump adviser linked to Turkish lobbying|work=Politico|accessdate=November 17, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Buzzfeed2">{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/borzoudaragahi/the-man-at-the-center-of-this-trump-scandal-wants-to-clear|publisher=[[BuzzFeed News]]|first=Borzou|last=Daragahi|date=June 20, 2017|title=The Man At The Center Of This Trump Scandal Wants To Clear His Name}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reflectionsturkey.com/?p=436|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208231232/http://www.reflectionsturkey.com/?p=436|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 8, 2015|title=The "Hidden" That Never Was|publisher=Reflections Turkey|accessdate=June 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/support-for-muslim-brotherhood-isolates-turkey/a-17037906|title=Support for Muslim Brotherhood isolates Turkey|publisher=Die Weld|accessdate=June 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brookings.edu/research/papers/2012/04/24-turkey-new-model-taspinar|title=Islamist Politics in Turkey: The New Model?|date=April 1, 2012|publisher=The Brookings Institution|author=Ömer Taşpınar|accessdate=June 7, 2015}}</ref>
On November 8 (election day in the United States), an op-ed written by Flynn was published by ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', calling for U.S. backing for Erdoğan's government and criticizing the regime's opponent, [[Fethullah Gülen]], alleging that Gülen headed a "vast global network" that fitted "the description of a dangerous sleeper terror network".<ref name=FlynnHillEd>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/foreign-policy/305021-our-ally-turkey-is-in-crisis-and-needs-our-support|title=Our ally Turkey is in crisis and needs our support|last=Anonymous|date=November 8, 2016|work=The Hill|access-date=March 9, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Schlberg1>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/mike-flynn-turkey-coup_us_58324909e4b099512f8376d4|title=Trump's National Security Adviser Changed His Mind About Turkey Coup Attempt After His Firm Got Involved|author=Jessica Schulberg Foreign Affairs|date=November 21, 2016|publisher=The Huffington Post|access-date=November 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>'' 'You don't haul somebody overseas': Ex CIA director says Michael Flynn may have gone too far in a meeting with Turkish officials'' http://uk.businessinsider.com/mike-flynn-turkey-lobbyist-james-woolsey-gulen-2017-3?r=US&IR=T</ref> At the time, Flynn did not disclose that his consulting firm had received funds from a company with ties to the Turkish government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://europe.newsweek.com/michael-rubin-trump-teams-first-ethics-scandal-521622?rm=eu|title=Michael Rubin: The Trump team's first ethics scandal|newspaper=Newsweek|access-date=November 18, 2016}}</ref> After Flynn's ties had been disclosed by ''[[The Daily Caller]]'', [[Politico]], and others, the editor of ''The Hill'' added a note to Flynn's op-ed, stating that Flynn had failed to disclose that he had been engaged at the time in "consulting work that might have aided the government of Turkey," that his firm had received payments from a company with close ties to the Turkish government, or that the company had reviewed the draft of the op-ed before it was submitted to ''The Hill''.<ref name=FlynnHillEd/>
On March 8, 2017, Flynn registered with the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] as a [[Foreign Agents Registration Act|foreign agent]] for $530,000 worth of lobbying work before election day.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/former-trump-security-adviser-flynn-admits-turkey-lobbying |title=Former Trump aide Flynn says lobbying may have helped Turkey |work=The Big Story |access-date=March 9, 2017 |language=en-US |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308234613/http://www.bigstory.ap.org/article/former-trump-security-adviser-flynn-admits-turkey-lobbying |archivedate=March 8, 2017 |df= }}</ref> This work was done on behalf of a Dutch-based company that may have been working for the Turkish government.<ref name=":6"/>
On March 24, 2017, former [[Director of the Central Intelligence Agency|Director of the CIA]] [[R. James Woolsey Jr.|James Woolsey]] said that in September 2016 Flynn, while working for the Trump presidential campaign, had attended a meeting in a New York hotel with Turkish officials including foreign minister Mevlut Cavusoglu and energy minister Berat Albayrak, son-in-law of Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and had discussed abducting [[Fethullah Gülen]] and sending him to Turkey, bypassing the U.S. extradition legal process.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ex-cia-director-mike-flynn-and-turkish-officials-discussed-removal-of-erdogan-foe-from-u-s-1490380426|title=Ex-CIA Director: Mike Flynn and Turkish Officials Discussed Removal of Erdogan Foe From U.S.|last=Grimaldi|first=James V.|date=March 24, 2017|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=March 25, 2017|last2=Nissenbaum|first2=Dion|issn=0099-9660|last3=Coker|first3=Margaret}}</ref>
Flynn sat in on classified national security briefings with then-candidate Trump at the same time that Flynn was working for foreign clients, which raises ethical concerns and conflicts of interest.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/michael-flynn-key-trump-aide-sat-in-on-intel-briefings-while-advising-foreign-clients-004512931.html|title=Michael Flynn, Trump's reported pick for national security adviser, sat in on intel briefings – while advising foreign clients|access-date=November 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/flynn-attended-intel-briefings-while-taking-money-lobby-turkey-n732041|title=Mike Flynn attended intelligence briefings while a lobbyist for Turkey|work=NBC News|access-date=June 29, 2017}}</ref> Flynn was paid at least $5,000 to serve as a consultant to a U.S.-Russian project to build 40 nuclear reactors across the Middle East, which Flynn's failure to disclose was flagged by Representatives [[Elijah Cummings]] and [[Eliot Engel]] as a possible violation of federal law.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-flynn/democrats-investigating-whether-flynn-promoted-reactor-project-as-trump-aide-idUSKCN1BO19G |publisher=[[Reuters]] |title=Democrats investigating whether Flynn promoted reactor project as Trump aide|first=Jonathan|last=Landay|first2=Warren|last2=Strobel|first3=Nathan|last3=Layne|date=September 13, 2017|access-date=December 1, 2017|editor-first=John|editor-last=Walcott|editor-first2=Peter|editor-last2=Cooney}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-13/flynn-omitted-a-saudi-nuclear-project-in-filing-democrats-say|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|title=Flynn Omitted a Saudi Nuclear Project in Filing, Democrats Say|first=Billy|last=House|date=September 13, 2017}}</ref>
===Attendance at RT gala dinner=== On December 10, 2015, Flynn attended a gala dinner in [[Moscow]] in honor of [[RT (TV network)|RT]] (formerly "Russia Today"), a Russian government-owned English-language media outlet, on which he made semi-regular appearances as an analyst after he retired from U.S. government service.<ref name="Emmarie">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/27/us/politics/michael-flynn-trump-investigation-defense-department.html|title=Pentagon Inquiry Seeks to Learn if Flynn Hid Foreign Payment|last1=Huetteman|first1=Emmarie|last2=Rosenberg|first2=Matthew|date=April 27, 2017|work=The New York Times|accessdate=June 1, 2017}}</ref>
Flynn sat next to Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] at the dinner, leading journalist [[Michael Crowley (journalist)|Michael Crowley]] of ''[[Politico]]'' to report that "at a moment of semi-hostility between the U.S. and Russia, the presence of such an important figure at Putin's table startled" U.S. officials.<ref name="Crowley">Michael Crowley, [http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/04/donald-trump-2016-russia-today-rt-kremlin-media-vladimir-putin-213833 The Kremlin's Candidate: In the 2016 election, Putin's propaganda network is picking sides], ''Politico Magazine'' (May/June 2016).</ref><ref name="Isikoff">Michael Isikoff, [https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-supporter-defends-payment-russian-175611942.html Top Trump adviser defends payment for Russian speaking engagement], Yahoo News (July 18, 2016).</ref><ref name=NYT23may17/> As part of the festivities, Flynn gave a talk on world affairs for which he was paid at least $45,000.<ref name = "Emmarie"/> Flynn defended the RT payment in an interview with [[Michael Isikoff]].<ref name="Isikoff"/>
On February 1, 2017, the [[Ranking member|ranking Democratic members]] on six House committees sent a letter to Secretary of Defense [[James Mattis]], requesting a [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] investigation into Flynn's connection to RT.<ref name="DemsLetter"> * {{cite news|first1=Shane|last1=Harris|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/democratic-lawmakers-seek-pentagon-probe-of-mike-flynns-russia-today-ties-1485970133|title=Democratic Lawmakers Seek Pentagon Probe of Mike Flynn's Russia Today Ties: National security adviser's connections with Russian television network under fire|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=February 1, 2017}} * {{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-flynn-congress-idUSKBN15G5MT|title=Democratic lawmakers want probe of Trump adviser's Russia payment|publisher=Reuters|date=February 1, 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/338146994/Mattis-Letter#from_embed|title=Letter to Secretary of Defense James Mattis|first1=Elijah E.|last1=Cummings|authorlink1=Elijah Cummings|first2=John Jr.|last2=Conyers|authorlink2=John Conyers|first3=Adam|last3=Schiff|authorlink3=Adam Schiff|first4=Adam|last4=Smith|authorlink4=Adam Smith (politician)|first5=Bennie G.|last5=Thompson|authorlink5=Bennie Thompson|first6=Eliot L.|last6=Engel|authorlink6=Eliot Engel|date=February 1, 2017}} </ref> The legislators expressed concern that Flynn had violated the [[Foreign Emoluments Clause]] of the [[United States Constitution|U.S. Constitution]] by accepting money from RT.<ref name="DemsLetter"/>
A 2017 report by the [[United States Intelligence Community]] characterized RT as "The Kremlin's principal international propaganda outlet" and said that [[RT America]] is set up as an autonomous nonprofit organization "to avoid the [[Foreign Agents Registration Act]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.intelligence.senate.gov/sites/default/files/documents/ICA_2017_01.pdf|title=Assessing Russian Activities and Intentions in Recent US Elections|publisher=United States Intelligence Community|date=January 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>Phillip Ewing, [https://www.npr.org/2017/02/10/514551968/5-things-on-michael-flynn-russia-and-donald-trump 5 Things On Michael Flynn, Russia and Donald Trump], NPR (February 10, 2017).</ref>
As a retired military intelligence officer, Flynn was required to obtain prior permission from the Defense Department and the State Department before receiving any money from foreign governments. Flynn apparently did not seek that approval before the RT speech, and he did not report the payment when he applied for renewal of his security clearance two months later.<ref name = "Emmarie" /> [[Glenn A. Fine]], the acting [[Office of the Inspector General, U.S. Department of Defense|Defense Department Inspector General]], has confirmed he is investigating Flynn.<ref name=NYT23may17/>
===2016 U.S. presidential election=== [[File:Michael Flynn (30020745053).jpg|right|thumb|Flynn at a campaign rally for then-Republican Presidential nominee Donald Trump, in October 2016]]
Having already been consulted regarding national security by Fiorina as well as other candidates, including [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]], [[Ben Carson]], [[Ted Cruz]], and [[Donald Trump]],<ref name="WAPO Aug 2016 interview">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/pb/news/checkpoint/wp/2016/08/15/trump-adviser-michael-t-flynn-on-his-dinner-with-putin-and-why-russia-today-is-just-like-cnn/?outputType=accessibility&nid=menu_nav_accessibilityforscreenreader |title=Trump adviser Michael T. Flynn on his dinner with Putin and why Russia Today is just like CNN |first=Dana|last=Priest|work=The Washington Post |date=August 15, 2016 |accessdate=August 16, 2016}}</ref> Flynn was asked in February 2016 to serve as an adviser to the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Trump campaign]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/7/9/12129202/michael-flynn-vice-president-donald-trump |title=Michael Flynn, the retired general on Donald Trump's VP shortlist, explained |first=Zack |last=Beauchamp |publisher=Vox |date=July 9, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, it was reported he was being considered as Trump's [[running mate]]; Flynn later confirmed that he had submitted [[Republican Party vice presidential candidate selection, 2016#Vetting process and selection|vetting documents]] to the campaign and, although a registered Democrat, was willing to accept the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] vice-presidential nomination if chosen.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/07/09/a-curveball-in-trumps-veep-search-hes-seriously-considering-a-retired-general/|title=A curveball in Trump's Veep search: He's seriously considering a retired general|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=July 11, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-vetting-gen-michael-flynn-potential-vp/story?id=40462921|title=Trump Vetting Gen. Michael Flynn for Potential VP Pick|publisher=ABC News|date=July 9, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2016}}</ref> However, Trump instead selected [[Governor of Indiana|Indiana Governor]] [[Mike Pence]].
As one of the keynote speakers during the first night of the [[2016 Republican National Convention]], Flynn gave what the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' described as a "fiery" speech, in which he stated: "We are tired of Obama's empty speeches and his misguided rhetoric. This, this has caused the world to have no respect for America's word, nor does it fear our might";<ref name="LATimes convention speech">{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/trailguide/la-na-republican-convention-2016-live-passed-over-as-vice-presidential-pick-1468897531-htmlstory.html|title=Retired Army Gen. Michael Flynn delivers fiery speech to emptying convention hall|work=Los Angeles Times|date=July 20, 2016|accessdate=August 16, 2016|first1=David S.|last1=Cloud|first2=Christine|last2=Mai-Duc}}</ref> he accused Obama of choosing to conceal the actions of [[Osama bin Laden]] and the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].<ref name="Regated">Regated. [http://regated.com/2016/07/reverse-redacted-michael-flynn-speech-highlights/ Reverse Redacted: Michael Flynn Speech Highlights] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161113181337/http://regated.com/2016/07/reverse-redacted-michael-flynn-speech-highlights|date=November 13, 2016}}</ref> Flynn went on to criticize [[Politically correct|political correctness]] and joined the crowd in a chant of "U-S-A! U-S-A!". During the chants, he told those in the audience, "Get fired up! This is about our country."<ref name="LATimes convention speech"/><ref name="keast1">{{cite news|last1=East|first1=Kristen|title=Republican National Convention 2016 schedule of speakers|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/rnc-events-speakers-convention-republicans-225683|accessdate=July 19, 2016|work=Politico|date=July 17, 2016}}</ref>
During the speech, Flynn launched a blistering attack on Democratic nominee [[Hillary Clinton]]. He led the crowd in chants of "Lock her up!"; during one of those chants, he encouraged the crowd to keep it up, saying, "Damn right! Exactly right! There is nothing wrong with that!"<ref name=Kitfield/> He called for Clinton to withdraw from the race, saying that "if I did a tenth of what she did, I'd be in jail today."<ref name=lock/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Dinan|first1=Stephen|title=Michael Flynn calls for Hillary Clinton to quit race, go to prison|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jul/18/michael-flynn-calls-hillary-clinton-quit-race-go-p/|work=The Washington Times|date=July 18, 2016}}</ref> He repeated in subsequent interviews that she should be "locked up".<ref name="WAPO Aug 2016 interview"/> While campaigning for Trump, Flynn also referred to Clinton as the "enemy camp".<ref name=lock/> Six days after the speech, Flynn stirred up a controversy by retweeting [[anti-Semitic]] remarks, which he later apologized for and claimed were unintentional.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/michael-flynn-twitter-226091|title=Flynn retweets anti-Semitic remark|publisher=Politico|access-date=July 24, 2016}}</ref> During the election campaign, Flynn used Twitter to post links to negative stories about Clinton, like the [[Pizzagate conspiracy theory]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|last1=Kaczynski|first1=Andrew|title=On Twitter, Michael Flynn interacted with alt-right, made controversial comments on Muslims, shared fake news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/18/politics/kfile-flynn-tweets|date=November 18, 2016|publisher=CNN|accessdate=December 18, 2016}}</ref>
Flynn was once opposed to [[waterboarding]] and other extreme interrogation techniques that have now been banned; however, according to an August 2016 ''Washington Post'' article, he said at one point, in the context of Trump's apparent openness to reinstating such techniques, that "he would be reluctant to take options off the table."<ref name=lock/> In May 2016, Flynn was asked by an [[Al Jazeera]] reporter if he would support Trump's stated plan to "take out [the] families"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://insider.foxnews.com/2015/12/02/donald-trump-fox-and-friends-we-have-take-out-isis-terrorists-families|title=Trump on Beating ISIS: 'You Have to Take Out Their Families'|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=December 2, 2015|accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Stein|first=Sam|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-terrorists_us_56e0d7cde4b065e2e3d4d82d|title=Trump Says He Never Pledged To Kill Family Members Of Terrorists|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=March 9, 2016|accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref> of people suspected of being involved in [[terrorism]]. In response, Flynn stated, "I would have to see the circumstances of that situation."<ref name=lock>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nearly-the-entire-national-security-establishment-has-rejected-trumpexcept-for-this-man/2016/08/15/d5072d96-5e4b-11e6-8e45-477372e89d78_story.html|title=He was one of the most respected intel officers of his generation. Now he's leading 'Lock her up' chants |access-date=August 16, 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=August 15, 2016}}</ref> In an interview with ''Al Jazeera'', Flynn criticized the U.S. reliance on drones as a "failed strategy", stating that "what we have is this continued investment in conflict. The more weapons we give, the more bombs we drop, that just ... fuels the conflict."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2015/07/16/retired-general-drones-create-terrorists-kill-iraq-war-helped-create-isis/|title=Retired General: Drones Create More Terrorists Than They Kill, Iraq War Helped Create ISIS|last=Hussain|first=Murtaza|date=|publisher=The Intercept |access-date=November 18, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/headtohead/2016/01/transcript-michael-flynn-160104174144334.html|title=Transcript: Michael Flynn on ISIL|publisher=Al Jazeera|access-date=November 18, 2016}}</ref>
==National Security Advisor== [[File:Trump visits MacDill Air Force Base (32715575096).jpg|thumb|Flynn, Gen. [[Joseph F. Dunford]], the chairman of the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]], Gen. [[Joseph Votel]] and Gen. [[Raymond A. Thomas]] at [[MacDill Air Force Base]], February 6, 2017.]] On November 10, 2016, President Obama warned President-elect Trump against hiring Flynn.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dovere|first1=Edward-Isaac|last2=Nussbaum|first2=Matthew|title=Obama warned Trump about Flynn, officials say|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/08/obama-warn-trump-michael-flynn-238116|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[Politico]]|date=May 8, 2017}}</ref> During their meeting in the [[Oval Office]] two days after the election, Obama expressed "profound concerns" about hiring Flynn to a sensitive, high-level national security post.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shear|first1=Michael D.|title=Obama Warned Trump About Hiring Flynn, Officials Say|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/08/us/politics/obama-flynn-trump.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 8, 2017}}</ref>
On November 18, 2016, Flynn accepted Trump's offer for the position of [[National Security Advisor]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/17/politics/trump-offers-flynn-job-of-national-security-adviser/ |title=Trump offers Flynn job of national security advisor |work=[[CNN]] |first1=Eric |last1=Bradner |first2=Sara |last2=Murray |first3=Ryan |last3=Browne |date=November 18, 2016 |access-date=May 27, 2017}}</ref> Prior to his appointment, media sources including ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and [[Associated Press]] had already criticized his close relations with Russia,<ref name=WaPoYates/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.apnews.com/ba462d64c12d4692b8381cb7076d34ab/AP-Source:-Trump-aide-in-frequent-contact-with-Russia-envoy|title=AP Source: Trump aide in frequent contact with Russia envoy|website=AP News|access-date=January 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Crowley" /><ref name="Isikoff" /> and his promotion of anti-[[Hillary Clinton|Clinton]] conspiracy theories and [[fake news]] during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/12/michael-flynn-conspiracy-pizzeria-trump-232227|title=Flynn under fire for fake news|newspaper=Politico|access-date=January 13, 2017}}</ref>
In December 2016, Flynn met with [[Heinz-Christian Strache]], leader of the far-right [[Freedom Party of Austria]] (FPA), at [[Trump Tower]] in New York.<ref name="Smale1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/19/world/europe/austrias-far-right-signs-a-cooperation-pact-with-putins-party.html |title=Austria's Far Right Signs a Cooperation Pact With Putin's Party|first=Alison|last=Smale|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 19, 2016|access-date=December 21, 2016}}</ref> The meeting attracted attention because the FPA was founded by ex-Nazis in the 1950s, and because Strache had recently signed a cooperation agreement with Vladimir Putin's ruling [[United Russia]] party. The Trump campaign refused to comment on the meeting.<ref name="Smale1" />
On December 29, 2016, Flynn spoke with Russian ambassador [[Sergey Kislyak]], the same day the Obama administration announced [[2016 United States election interference by Russia#Sanctions imposed on Russia|retaliatory measures]] in response to the [[2016 United States election interference by Russia|interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign]] by the Russian government. The phone conversation was reportedly viewed by Obama advisers who had been briefed on its content by the F.B.I. with suspicion as possibly a secret deal between the incoming team and Moscow, which could have violated the dormant [[Logan Act]] that bars unauthorized U.S. citizens from negotiating with foreign powers in disputes with the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/14/us/politics/fbi-interviewed-mike-flynn.html|title=Flynn's Downfall Sprang From 'Eroding Level of Trust'|last2=Davis|first2=Julie Hirschfeld|date=February 14, 2017|publisher=|first1=Peter Baker, Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman, Adam|last1=Goldman|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/02/logan-act-michael-flynn-trump-russia/516774/|title=Did Michael Flynn Violate the Logan Act?|first=Clare|last=Foran|work=The Atlantic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/explaining-logan-act-dems-mike-flynn-violated/story?id=45481930|title=Explaining the Logan Act that Dems say Mike Flynn may have violated|first=|last=|date=February 16, 2017|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> The day after reporting by [[David Ignatius]], Trump's incoming press secretary, [[Sean Spicer]] said the conversation had occurred on December 28 and thus couldn't have touched on the retaliation measures or Russia's response; Spicer later had to correct himself on the date of the conversation.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Keith|first1=Tamara|last2=Montanaro|first2=Domenico |date=January 14, 2017 |title=Trump Team: Adviser Spoke to Russia Official The Day U.S. Sanctions Were Announced|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/01/14/509780474/trump-team-top-advisor-spoke-to-russia-official-before-u-s-sanctions-were-announ|publisher=NPR}}</ref>
[[File:Shinzō Abe and Donald Trump (3).jpg|thumb|Japanese Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] meets with President-elect Trump, Kushner and Flynn in November 2016]]
On January 4, 2017, Flynn informed [[Don McGahn]], soon to become the [[White House Counsel]], that he was under investigation over his work for Turkey.<ref>{{cite news|last1=[[Matthew Rosenberg]]|last2=[[Mark Mazzetti]]|title=Trump Team Knew Flynn Was Under Investigation Before He Came to White House|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/17/us/politics/michael-flynn-donald-trump-national-security-adviser.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 18, 2017|page=A1}}</ref> Ten days before the [[inauguration of Donald Trump]], Flynn told then-National Security Advisor [[Susan Rice]] not to proceed with a planned [[Raqqa campaign (2016–present)|invasion of Raqqa]] using Kurdish [[People's Protection Units]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bergengruen|first1=Vera|title=Flynn stopped military plan Turkey opposed – after being paid as its agent|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/white-house/article151149647.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[McClatchy DC]]|date=May 17, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Flynn's decision would delay the campaign, which had taken seven months to plan, several more months, but was consistent with Turkish objections to working with Kurdish troops.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Entous|first1=Adam|last2=Jaffe|first2=Greg|last3=Ryan|first3=Missy|title=Obama's White House worked for months on a plan to seize Raqqa. Trump's team took a brief look and decided not to pull the trigger.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/obamas-white-house-worked-for-months-on-a-plan-to-seize-raqqa-trumps-team-deemed-it-hopelessly-inadequate/2017/02/02/116310fa-e71a-11e6-80c2-30e57e57e05d_story.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=February 2, 2017}}</ref>
Acting Attorney General [[Sally Yates]], in May 8 testimony before the [[Senate Judiciary Committee]]'s [[United States Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism|Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism]], said the FBI interviewed Flynn, on January 24, 2017. Based on the results of that interview, she made an "urgent" request to meet with McGahn.<ref name="King">{{cite news|url=http://www.11alive.com/news/politics/national-politics/sally-yates-and-michael-flynn-the-timeline-of-events/437827791|title=Sally Yates warned White House Michael Flynn was vulnerable to Russian blackmail|last=King|first=Michael|date=May 8, 2017|work=WXIA|accessdate=May 9, 2017}}</ref> She met with him on January 26 and again on January 27.<ref name="Borger">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/may/08/sally-yates-trump-russia-michael-flynn-blackmail-compromised|title=Mike Flynn at risk of Russian blackmail, Sally Yates warned White House|last=Borger|first=Julian|date=May 8, 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=May 9, 2017}}</ref> She informed McGahn that Flynn was "compromised" and possibly open to blackmail by the Russians. Yates told McGahn that Flynn had misled Pence and other administration officials about the nature of his conversation with the Russian ambassador.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Apuzzo|first1=Matt|last2=Huetteman|first2=Emmarie|title=Sally Yates Tells Senators She Warned Trump About Michael Flynn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/08/us/politics/michael-flynn-sally-yates-hearing.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 9, 2017|page=A1}}</ref><ref name=WaPoYates>{{cite news|last1=Entous|first1=Adam|last2=Nakashima|first2=Ellen|last3=Rucker|first3=Philip|title=Justice Department warned White House that Flynn could be vulnerable to Russian blackmail, officials say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/justice-department-warned-white-house-that-flynn-could-be-vulnerable-to-russian-blackmail-officials-say/2017/02/13/fc5dab88-f228-11e6-8d72-263470bf0401_story.html|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=February 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/05/08/yates-says-flynn-could-have-been-blackmailed-clapper-knocks-collusion-narrative.html|title=Yates says Flynn could have been 'blackmailed,' Clapper knocks collusion narrative|date=May 8, 2017|work=Fox News|accessdate=May 8, 2017}}</ref> She added that Flynn's "underlying conduct", which she could not describe due to classification, "was problematic in and of itself," saying "(i)t was a whole lot more than one White House official lying to another."<ref name = "Borger" /><ref name = "King" /> Former [[United States Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]] called the possibility of Flynn being blackmailed "kind of a stretch," while acknowledging that his false statement was "a problem ... that I would tell the president about."<ref>{{cite web|last=Watson|first=Kathryn|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/robert-gates-says-flynn-blackmail-fears-are-kind-of-a-stretch/|title=Robert Gates says Flynn blackmail fears are "kind of a stretch"|work=[[CBS News]]|date=May 14, 2017|accessdate=July 13, 2017}}</ref>
On January 22, 2017, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that Flynn was under investigation by U.S. counterintelligence agents for his communications with Russian officials.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-eyes-michael-flynns-links-to-russia-1485134942|title=U.S. Eyes Michael Flynn's Links to Russia|last=Lee|first=Carol E.|date=January 23, 2017|last2=Barrett|first2=Devlin|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|last3=Harris|first3=Shane|access-date=January 23, 2017|subscription=yes}}</ref> On February 8, 2017, Flynn flatly denied having spoken to Kislyak in December 2016 about the [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis|sanctions placed on Russia]] by the Obama administration; however, the next day, U.S. intelligence officials shared an account indicating that such discussions did in fact take place.<ref name=WaPoSanctions>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/national-security-adviser-flynn-discussed-sanctions-with-russian-ambassador-despite-denials-officials-say/2017/02/09/f85b29d6-ee11-11e6-b4ff-ac2cf509efe5_story.html|title=National security adviser Flynn discussed sanctions with Russian ambassador, despite denials, officials say|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> Following this revelation, Flynn's spokesman released a statement that Flynn "indicated that while he had no recollection of discussing sanctions, he couldn't be certain that the topic never came up".<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Cilliza|first1=Cliff|title=Just how much trouble is Michael Flynn in?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/02/10/just-how-much-trouble-is-michael-flynn-in|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>
===Dismissal and investigation=== [[File:Michael Flynn Resignation Letter.pdf|thumb|Michael T. Flynn resignation letter]] On February 13, 2017, Flynn resigned as National Security Advisor, following news reports about his communications with the Russian ambassador, [[Sergey Kislyak]] and additional reports that he had misled the Vice President about them.<ref name="NYTResign">{{cite news|last1=[[Maggie Haberman]]|last2=[[Matthew Rosenberg]]|last3=[[Matt Apuzzo]]|last4=[[Glenn Thrush]]|title=Michael Flynn Resigns as National Security Adviser|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/13/us/politics/donald-trump-national-security-adviser-michael-flynn.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 14, 2017|page=A1}}</ref> Flynn's 24-day tenure as National Security Advisor was the shortest in the 63-year history of the office.<ref name="HawkinsShortest"/> Those communications he had with the Russian ambassador were subsequently leaked to the press.<ref>Crowley, Michael. [https://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/susan-rice-flynn-unmasking-236884 “Susan Rice becomes the target of conservative attacks over Flynn unmasking”], ''[[Politico]]'' (April 4, 2017): "Flynn's name was reportedly among those unmasked, and later leaked to the media, revealing contacts he had with the Russian ambassador in December, which cost him his job after it became clear he had misrepresented them to fellow White House officials."</ref>
Commenting on Flynn′s resignation, on February 14 White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer stated, "We got to a point not based on a legal issue, but based on a trust issue, where a level of trust between the President and General Flynn had eroded to the point where he felt he had to make a change ... The issue here was that the President got to the point where General Flynn's relationship – misleading the Vice President and others, or the possibility that he had forgotten critical details of this important conversation had created a critical mass and an unsustainable situation. That's why the President decided to ask for his resignation, and he got it."<ref>[https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/02/14/press-briefing-press-secretary-sean-spicer-2142017-12 Press Briefing by Press Secretary Sean Spicer, 2/14/2017, #12] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215210113/https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/02/14/press-briefing-press-secretary-sean-spicer-2142017-12 |date=February 15, 2017 }} The White House: Office of the Press Secretary, February 14, 2017.</ref>
That same day (February 14), President Trump met with FBI Director [[James Comey]] in the Oval Office and reportedly told him "I hope you can see your way clear to letting this go, to letting Flynn go" adding "he's a good guy."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schmidt|first1=Michael S.|title=Comey Memo Says Trump Asked Him to End Flynn Investigation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/16/us/politics/james-comey-trump-flynn-russia-investigation.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 17, 2017|page=A1}}</ref> Comey subsequently testified that, "I had understood the President to be requesting that we drop any investigation of Flynn in connection with false statements about his conversations with the Russian ambassador in December ... I did not understand the president to be talking about the broader investigation into Russia or possible links to his campaign".<ref>Dilanian, Ken. [https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/amp/comey-testify-he-assured-trump-he-was-not-personally-under-n769326 "Comey to Testify He Assured Trump He Was Not Personally Under Investigation"], [[NBC News]] (June 7, 2017).</ref> The propriety, and even the legality, of these words that Trump reportedly said to Comey about Flynn have become a subject of considerable public debate.<ref>Farivar, Masood. [https://www.voanews.com/a/can-trump-be-indicted-for-obstruction-of-justice/3894827.html "Can Trump Be Indicted for Obstruction of Justice?"], [[VOA News]] (June 10, 2017).</ref> Several months after dismissing Flynn, Trump also [[Dismissal of James Comey|dismissed Comey]], which Comey attributed to the FBI's Russia investigation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/News/world/americas/us-politics/comey-testimony-trump-what-happened-say-highlights-quotes-obstruction-justice-takeaways-a7780156.html|title=Comey testimony: The five biggest things we learnt from his damning Senate hearing on Trump|last=Sampathkumar|first=Mythili|date=June 8, 2017|work=The Independent|accessdate=June 9, 2017}}</ref>
Flynn had offered to testify to the FBI or the Senate and [[House Intelligence committee]]s relating to the Russia probe in exchange for immunity from criminal prosecution.<ref name="wsj-immunity">{{Cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mike-flynn-offers-to-testify-in-exchange-for-immunity-1490912959 |title=Mike Flynn Offers to Testify in Exchange for Immunity |date=March 30, 2017 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref> However, the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]] rejected Flynn's offer for testimony in exchange for immunity.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michael Flynn's Immunity Request Rejected By Senate Intelligence Committee|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/senate-intelligence-committee-rejects-immunity-michael-flynn-n741061|accessdate=March 31, 2017|publisher=NBC News|date=April 1, 2017}}</ref> Flynn initially declined to respond to a [[subpoena]] from the Senate Intelligence Committee, invoking his [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]] right against [[self-incrimination]], but he and the committee later struck a compromise.<ref name=NYT23may17/><ref name="cbsnews.com"/> The [[Office of the Inspector General, U.S. Department of Defense|Pentagon inspector general]] is also investigating whether Flynn accepted money from foreign governments without the required approval.<ref name=inspector/>
On November 5, 2017, [[NBC News]] reported that [[Robert Mueller]] has enough evidence for charges against Flynn and his son; Michael G. Flynn.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/mueller-has-enough-evidence-bring-charges-flynn-investigation-n817666|title=Mueller Has Enough Evidence to Bring Charges in Flynn Investigation|date=November 5, 2017|work=NBC News|accessdate=November 24, 2017}}</ref> On November 10, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that Flynn is under investigation by Mueller for allegedly planning a [[kidnapping]] and [[extrajudicial]] rendition of Turkish cleric [[Fethullah Gülen]] to [[Turkey]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mueller-probes-flynns-role-in-alleged-plan-to-deliver-cleric-to-turkey-1510309982|title=Mueller Probes Flynn's Role in Alleged Plan to Deliver Cleric to Turkey|last=Grimaldi|first=James V.|date=November 10, 2017|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |access-date=November 10, 2017|last2=Harris|first2=Shane|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660|last3=Viswanatha|first3=Aruna}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Mueller probing alleged Flynn plan to deliver cleric to Turkey: WSJ |publisher=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia/mueller-probing-alleged-flynn-plan-to-deliver-cleric-to-turkey-wsj-idUSKBN1DA1S6 |quote=Special counsel Robert Mueller is investigating whether U.S. President Donald Trump's first national security adviser, Michael Flynn, was involved in an alleged plan to seize a Muslim cleric and deliver him to Turkey in exchange for millions of dollars, ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported on Friday. |first=Doina |last=Chiacu |editor-first=Bernadette |editor-last=Baum |date=November 10, 2017 |access-date=November 10, 2017}}</ref> On November 22, ''NBC News'' reported that Michael T. Flynn's business partner [[Bijan Kian]] is a subject of the Mueller probe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/mike-flynn-business-partner-bijan-kian-now-subject-mueller-probe-n823366|title=Mueller eyes Mike Flynn business partner Bijan Kian|work=NBC News|access-date=November 23, 2017|language=en}}</ref> NBC has also reported that a Turkish businessman named [[Reza Zarrab]], who was picked up last year by U.S. authorities in Miami on Iranian sanctions violations and money laundering charges, is offering evidence against the subject.<ref>Köksal, Nil. (20 November 2017). "ANALYSIS Who is Reza Zarrab? Turkish-Iranian gold trader may be working with Mueller investigation of Michael Flynn". [http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/who-is-reza-zarrab-turkish-iranian-gold-trader-may-be-working-with-mueller-investigation-of-michael-flynn-1.4409930 CBC News website] Retrieved 3 December 2017.</ref><ref>Lee, Carol E. & Ainsley, Julia. (10 November 2017). "Mueller Probing Possible Deal Between Turks, Flynn During Presidential Transition". [https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/mueller-probing-possible-deal-between-turks-flynn-during-presidential-transition-n819616 NBC News website] Retrieved 3 December 2017.</ref>
On November 23, 2017, it was reported that Flynn's lawyers have notified Trump's legal team they can no longer discuss anything regarding Mueller's investigation, suggesting that Flynn may be cooperating with prosecutors or negotiating a deal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/23/us/politics/flynn-mueller-russia-trump.html|title=A Split From Trump Indicates That Flynn Is Moving to Cooperate With Mueller|last=Schmidt|first=Michael S.|date=November 23, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 24, 2017|last2=Apuzzo|first2=Matt|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=Haberman|first3=Maggie}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/23/politics/michael-flynn-donald-trump-robert-mueller-new-york-times/index.html|title=Flynn's lawyers no longer sharing information with Trump's legal team|last=CNN|first=Sophie Tatum and Evan Perez,|work=CNN|access-date=November 24, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.axios.com/new-sign-flynn-may-be-cooperating-with-mueller-2512000628.html|title=New sign Flynn may be planning to cooperate with Mueller|date=November 23, 2017|work=Axios|access-date=November 24, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
===Plea bargain and statement of offense=== {{Further|Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)}} [[File:Flynn statement of offense.pdf|thumb|Flynn statement of offense]] On December 1, 2017, special counsel [[Robert Mueller]] agreed to a [[plea bargain]] where Flynn pleaded guilty to "willfully and knowingly" [[Making false statements|making "false, fictitious and fraudulent statements"]] to the FBI regarding conversations with Russia's ambassador. Specifically, Flynn is accused of falsely claiming that he had not asked Russia's ambassador to the United States [[Sergey Kislyak]] on December 29, 2016, "to refrain from escalating the situation in response to sanctions that the United States had imposed against Russia that same day."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Tucker|last2=Mangan|first2=Dan|title=Michael Flynn, Trump's ex-national security adviser, is expected to plead guilty Friday to lying to the FBI|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/12/01/court-schedules-plea-hearing-for-flynn-at-1030-am-et.html|accessdate=December 1, 2017|publisher=[[CNBC]]|date=December 1, 2017}}</ref> Flynn pleaded guilty the same day and acknowledged that he was cooperating with the investigation by Mueller.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sullivan|first1=Eileen|last2=Goldman|first2=Adam|last3=Shear|first3=Michael D.|title=Michael Flynn Pleads Guilty to Lying to the F.B.I.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/01/us/politics/michael-flynn-guilty-russia-investigation.html|accessdate=December 1, 2017|agency=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=December 1, 2017}}</ref> Flynn stated;<ref>Ross, Brian et al. [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/michael-flynn-charged-making-false-statements-fbi-documents/story?id=50849354 "Flynn has promised special counsel 'full cooperation' in Russia probe: Source"], [[ABC News]] (December 1, 2017).</ref>
<blockquote>It has been extraordinarily painful to endure these many months of false accusations of "treason" and other outrageous acts....Such false accusations are contrary to everything I have ever done and stood for. But I recognize that the actions I acknowledged in court today were wrong, and, through my faith in God, I am working to set things right.</blockquote>
''Bloomberg'' reporter [[Eli Lake]] wrote in an [[opinion piece]] on December 1, 2017, that two former Trump transition team officials provided information indicating that [[Jared Kushner]] was the senior member of the team described in Flynn's plea documents as having directed Flynn to contact officials from foreign governments, including Russia, asking them to delay or vote against a [[United Nations]] resolution on the issue of [[Israeli settlements]], contrary to the still-incumbent Obama administration's position of support for the resolution.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-12-01/kushner-is-said-to-have-ordered-flynn-to-contact-russia|title=Kushner Is Said to Have Ordered Flynn to Contact Russia|date=December 1, 2017|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=December 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>Melissa Quinn | Washington Examiner, Jared Kushner directed Michael Flynn to contact Russian government in Dec. 2016: Report, http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/jared-kushner-directed-michael-flynn-to-contact-russian-government-in-dec-2016-report/article/2642306 , January 12, 2017</ref> This was also confirmed by other news outlets, who cited multiple sources.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Santucci |first1=John |last2=Palmeri |first2=Tara |last3=Kelsey |first3=Adam |date=December 1, 2017 |title=Jared Kushner is 'very senior' official who directed Flynn to contact Russia in court documents: Sources |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/senior-trump-transition-official-directed-flynn-contact-russia/story?id=51515179 |publisher=ABC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=December 1, 2017 |title=Kushner, McFarland talked to Flynn about Russia |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/kushner-mcfarland-talked-to-flynn-about-russia/ |publisher=CBS News}}</ref>
Sentencing of Flynn has been deferred several times,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/371722-mueller-flynn-legal-teams-not-ready-to-schedule-a-sentencing |title=Mueller, Flynn legal teams not ready to schedule a sentencing hearing |last=Bowden |first=John |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|access-date=2018-02-14}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/regulation/administration/385740-mueller-requests-flynns-sentencing-be-delayed-at-least-two-more |title=Mueller requests Flynn's sentencing be delayed at least two more months |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |first=Brett |last=Samuels |date=May 1, 2018 |access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> the last time on July 10, 2018.<ref>{{cite news|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |title= Judge again delays sentencing for Michael Flynn, Trump's former national security advisor |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-mike-flynn-court-20180710-story.html |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=July 10, 2018 |access-date=July 10, 2018 }}</ref> As part of Flynn's plea negotiations, his son, Michael G. Flynn, is not expected to be charged.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/michael-flynn-charged-with-making-false-statement-to-the-fbi/2017/12/01/e03a6c48-d6a2-11e7-9461-ba77d604373d_story.html|title=Michael Flynn pleads guilty to lying to the FBI|last=Leonnig|first=Carol D.|date=December 1, 2017|work=The Washington Post |access-date=December 1, 2017|last2=Dawsey|first2=Josh|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|last3=Barrett|first3=Devlin|last4=Zapotosky|first4=Matt}}</ref>
==Political views== Flynn is a registered [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], having grown up in a "very strong Democratic family".<ref name=CNNjuly10>{{cite news|last1=Diaz|first1=Daniella|title=Flynn voices abortion views at odds with Republican platform|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/10/politics/lt-gen-michael-flynn-donald-trump-vice-president-abc-this-week-dallas-shooting/|accessdate=July 10, 2016|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=July 10, 2016}}</ref> However, he was a keynote speaker during the first night of the [[2016 Republican National Convention]],<ref name="LATimes convention speech"/> and he was a surrogate and top national security adviser for President [[Donald Trump]].
During a July 10, 2016, interview on ABC News' ''[[This Week (ABC TV series)|This Week]]'', when asked by host [[Martha Raddatz]] about the [[Abortion in the United States|issue of abortion]], Flynn stated, "women have to be able to choose."<ref name=CNNjuly10/><ref name=ABCjuly10>{{cite news|last1=Kelsey|first1=Adam|title=Possible Trump VP Pick Flynn Supports Abortion Rights: 'Women Have to Be Able to Choose'|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-vp-pick-flynn-supports-abortion-rights-woman/story?id=40465180|accessdate=July 10, 2016|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=July 10, 2016}}</ref> The next day, Flynn said on [[Fox News]] that he is a "[[pro-life]] Democrat".<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/07/11/trump-vp-short-lister-flynn-clarifies-abortion-stance-says-hes-pro-life.html|title=Trump VP short-lister Flynn clarifies abortion stance, says he's 'pro-life'|first=Jennifer|last=Griffin|date=July 11, 2016|publisher=[[Fox News]] |accessdate=July 11, 2016}}</ref>
Flynn is a supporter of current Israeli policies.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jerusalem said to welcome Trump's 'pro-Israel' security picks |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/jerusalem-said-to-welcome-trumps-pro-israel-security-picks/ |work=The Times of Israel |date=November 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Trump's Transition Team Colluded With Israel. Why Isn't That News? |url=https://theintercept.com/2017/12/05/michael-flynn-jared-kushner-israel-settlements-trump/ |work=The Intercept |date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> He is also an opponent of the [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action|Iran nuclear deal]]. In February 2017, Flynn said that "the Obama administration failed to respond adequately to Tehran's malign actions – including weapons transfers, support for terrorism and other violations of international norms".<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump administration: 'We are officially putting Iran on notice' |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38832407 |work=BBC News |date=February 2, 2017}}</ref> Flynn accused [[Yemen]]'s [[Houthi insurgency in Yemen|Houthi rebels]] of being one of Iran's "proxy terrorist groups" in February 2017.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump risks deeper entanglement in Yemen's murky war |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-trump-idUSKBN15M1HP |agency=Reuters |date=February 7, 2017}}</ref> Flynn also criticized Obama's administration for [[Timber Sycamore|arming Syrian rebels]] linked to [[Salafi jihadism]].<ref name="aljazeera">{{cite news |title=Transcript: Michael Flynn on ISIL |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/headtohead/2016/01/transcript-michael-flynn-160104174144334.html |work=Al-Jazeera |date=January 13, 2016}}</ref> According to Flynn, the U.S. is "at war with a radical component of [[Islam]]".<ref name="aljazeera"/> Flynn has been a board member of [[ACT! for America]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-national-security-adviser-mike-flynn-called/story?id=43575658|title=Trump's National Security Adviser Has Called Islam 'a Cancer'|last=Khan|first=Mariam|date=November 18, 2016|publisher=ABC News |access-date=November 18, 2016}}</ref> and sees the Muslim faith as one of the root causes of Islamist terrorism.<ref name=":1"/> He has described Islam as a [[political ideology]] and a [[eliminationism|cancer]].<ref name=":1"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://qz.com/841197/islam-is-a-malignant-cancer-the-hateful-rhetoric-of-michael-flynn-trumps-new-national-security-adviser/|title=Islam is a 'malignant cancer': The hateful rhetoric of Trump's new national security adviser|last=Mangla|first=Ismat Sarah|publisher=Quartz |access-date=November 18, 2016}}</ref> He once tweeted that "fear of Muslims is RATIONAL"<ref name=":2" /> and included a video link claiming that Islam wants "80% of people enslaved or exterminated".<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump's national-security team takes shape: Jim Mattis would be a reassuring choice; Mike Flynn is an alarming one|url=https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21710812-jim-mattis-would-be-reassuring-choice-mike-flynn-alarming-one-donald-trumps|accessdate=November 26, 2016|work=[[The Economist]]|date=November 26, 2016}}</ref> Initially supportive of Trump's proposal to ban Muslims from entering the US, Flynn later told Al Jazeera that a blanket ban was unworkable and has called instead for "vetting" of entrants from countries like Syria.<ref name=":2" /> Flynn has stated the U.S. "should extradite [[Fethullah Gülen]]" to [[Turkey]] and "work constructively with Russia" in Syria.<ref name="Hersh"/><ref>{{Cite news |last=Sanger|first=David E.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/12/world/middleeast/donald-trump-syria.html?_r=0|title=Donald Trump Likely to End Aid for Rebels Fighting Syrian Government|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 11, 2016|accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref> In 2016, he said that he had personally seen photos of signs in the Southwest border area that were in [[Arabic (language)|Arabic]] to help Muslims entering the United States illegally.
