An officer of the [[National Border Patrol Council]] responded that the organization was not aware of any such signs.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/12/08/politics/kfile-michael-flynn-arabic-signs-on-border/index.html |title=Michael Flynn once claimed Arabic signs on southern border guide 'radicalized Muslims' into US |last=Kaczynski |first=Andrew |date=December 10, 2016 |publisher=[[CNN]] |access-date= December 12, 2016}}</ref>
==Writings== Flynn co-authored a report in January 2010 through the [[Center for a New American Security]], entitled ''Fixing Intel: A Blueprint for Making Intelligence Relevant in Afghanistan''.<ref name="Fixing Intel">{{cite web |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/files.cnas.org/documents/AfghanIntel_Flynn_Jan2010_code507_voices.pdf|title=Fixing Intel: A Blueprint for Making Intelligence Relevant in Afghanistan |publisher=Center for a New American Security |date=January 2010 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |author1=Michael T. Flynn |author2=Captain Matt Pottinger |author-link2=Matthew Pottinger |author3=Paul D. Batchelor }}</ref> That report, which became influential,<ref>Landler, Mark and Perlez, Jane. [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/world/asia/matthew-pottinger-trump-china.html?_r=0 "A Veteran and China Hand Advises Trump for Xi’s Visit"], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (April 4, 2017).</ref> argued that U.S. intelligence agencies "must open their doors to anyone who is willing to exchange information, including Afghans and NGOs (non-governmental organizations) as well as the US military and its allies".<ref>Mitchell, Peter. [http://www.news.com.au/world/breaking-news/top-trump-adviser-defends-aust-dealings/news-story/1c9b10b6d911b0ad49b1ed314ffc2848 "Top Trump adviser defends Aust dealings"], [[Australian Associated Press]] (November 21, 2016).</ref>
Flynn is also an author of ''[[The Field of Fight|The Field of Fight: How We Can Win the Global War Against Radical Islam and Its Allies]]'', co-authored with [[Michael Ledeen]], which was published by [[St. Martin's Press]] in 2016.<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Flynn |first1=Michael T.|last2=Ledeen|first2=Michael |title= The Field of Fight: How We Can Win the Global War Against Radical Islam and Its Allies|publisher = St. Martin's Press|date=2016|ISBN = 1250106222|OCLC= | ref = harv }}</ref> In reviewing the book, [[Will McCants]] of the [[Brookings Institution]] described Flynn's worldview as a confused combination of [[neoconservatism]] (an insistence on destroying what he sees as an alliance of tyranny, dictatorships, and radical Islamist regimes) and [[Realism (international relations)|realism]] (support for working with "friendly tyrants"), although he acknowledged that this could be due to the book having two authors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brookings.edu/blogs/markaz/posts/2016/07/19-michael-flynn-trump-isis-mccants|title=Realist or neocon? Mixed messages in Trump advisor's foreign policy vision|date=July 19, 2016 |author=[[Will McCants]]|publisher=Markaz: Middle East Politics & Policy (Brookings Institution blog)}}</ref>

[[File:MosesShapira.jpg|thumb|Moses Shapira.]] '''Moses Wilhelm Shapira''' ({{lang-he|מוזס וילהלם שפירא}}; 1830 – March 9, 1884) was a [[Jerusalem]] antiquities dealer and purveyor of allegedly forged [[Biblical artifact]]s.<ref name="Allegro1965">{{cite book|first=John Marco |last=Allegro|title=The Shapira affair|year=1965|publisher=Doubleday}}</ref><ref name="Vermès2010">{{cite book|first=Géza |last=Vermès|title=The story of the scrolls: the miraculous discovery and true significance of the Dead Sea scrolls|year=2010|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-0-14-104615-0|authorlink=Géza Vermes}}</ref> The shame brought about by accusations that he was involved in the forging of ancient biblical texts drove him to suicide in 1884. The discovery of the [[Dead Sea scrolls]] in 1947, in approximately the same area he claimed his material was discovered, has cast some doubt on the original forgery charges.<ref name="Allegro1965"/><ref name="Vermès2010"/>
== Early life and career == Moses Wilhelm Shapira was born in 1830 to [[Poland|Polish]]-[[Jew]]ish parents in [[Kamenets-Podolski]], which at the time was part of [[Russia]]n-annexed [[Poland]] (in modern-day [[Ukraine]]). Shapira's father emigrated to [[History of Palestine#Ottoman era|Ottoman Palestine]] and in 1856, at the age of 25, Moses Shapira followed. His grandfather, who accompanied him, died en route.
On the way, while in [[Bucharest]], Moses Shapira converted to Christianity and applied for [[Germany|German]] citizenship. Once in Jerusalem, he joined the community of [[Anglicanism|Anglican]] missionaries and converts<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|last=Singer|first=Isidore|author2=Joseph Jacobs|title=SHAPIRA, M. W.|encyclopedia=Jewish Encyclopedia|pages=232–233|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=556&letter=S}}</ref> and in 1861 opened a store<ref>{{EB1911|title=Shapira, M. W.|author=Unsigned|volume=24|page=803|url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri24chisrich#page/802/mode/2up}}</ref> in the Street of the Christians, today's Christian Quarter Road. He sold the usual religious souvenirs enjoyed by pilgrims, as well as ancient pots he acquired from [[Arab]] farmers.
== Moabite forgeries == Shapira became interested in biblical artifacts after the appearance of the so-called Moabite Stone, also known as the [[Mesha Stele]]. He witnessed the huge interest around it and may have had a hand in negotiating on behalf of the German representatives. [[France]] eventually got the fragments of the original stone, leaving the [[England|British]] and the Germans rather frustrated.
The [[squeeze (copying method)|squeeze]] which helped reconstruct the shattered Mesha Stele was taken on behalf of the French scholar and diplomat [[Charles Simon Clermont-Ganneau|Charles Clermont-Ganneau]] by a [[Christian Arab]] painter and ''dragoman'' (tour-guide), Salim al-Khouri, better known as '''Salim al-Kari''', "the reader", a nickname apparently given to him by the [[Bedouin]] due to his work with ancient alphabets. Salim soon became Shapira's associate and provided connections to Arab craftsmen who, along with Salim himself, produced for Shapira's shop large amounts of fake Moabite artifacts – large stone-made human heads, but mainly clay objects: vessels, figurines and erotic pieces, generously covered with inscriptions based chiefly on the signs Salim had copied from the Mesha Stele. To modern scholars, the products seem clumsy – inscriptions do not translate to anything legible, for one – but at the time there was little with which to compare them. Shapira even organized an expedition to Moab for potential buyers, to sites where he had Salim's [[Bedouin]] associates bury more forgeries. Some scholars began to base theories on these pieces and the term Moabitica was coined for this entirely new category of "Moabite" artifacts.
Since German archaeologists had not gained possession of the Moabite Stone, they rushed to buy the Shapira Collection ahead of their rivals. Berlin's [[Altes Museum]] bought 1700 artifacts for the cost of 22,000 [[thaler]]s in 1873. Other private collectors followed suit. One of them was [[Horatio Kitchener]], a not yet famous British lieutenant, who bought eight pieces for the [[Palestine Exploration Fund]]. Shapira was able to move to the luxurious [[Agha (Ottoman Empire)|Aga]] [[Nashashibi|Rashid]] property (modern-day [[Ticho House]]), outside Jerusalem's squalid [[Old City (Jerusalem)|Old City]], with his wife and two daughters.
Still various people, including Charles Clermont-Ganneau, had their doubts. Clermont-Ganneau suspected Salim al-Kari, questioned him and in time found the man who supplied him with clay, a stonemason who worked for him, and other accomplices. He published his findings in the ''Athenaeum'' newspaper in [[London]] and declared all "Moabitica" to be forgeries, a conclusion with which even the German scholars eventually concurred (cf. [[Emil Friedrich Kautzsch]] and [[:de:Albert Socin|Albert Socin]], ''Die Echtheit der moabitischen Altertümer geprüft'', 1876). Shapira defended his collection vigorously until his rivals presented more evidence against them. He placed the entire blame on Salim al-Kari, convinced almost everyone that he was just an innocent victim, and continued to do a considerable trade especially in genuine old [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] manuscripts from [[Yemen]].
== Manuscript forgeries == {{main| Shapira Scroll}} [[File:Punch 1883 Mr Sharp-Eye-Ra. Showing, in very fanciful portraiture, how Detective Ginsburg actually did Mr Sharp-Eye-Ra out of his skin.jpg|thumb|1883 [[Punch magazine]] cartoon of Shapira and Ginsburg]]
In 1883 Shapira presented what is now known as the ''Shapira Strips'', a supposedly ancient scroll written on leather strips which he claimed had been found near the [[Dead Sea]]. The Hebrew text hinted at a different version of [[Deuteronomy]], including a surprising [[Ten Commandments|eleventh commandment]] ("Thou shalt not hate thy brother in thy heart: I am God, thy God"). Shapira sought to sell them to the [[British Museum]] for a million [[pound sterling|pound]]s, and allowed them to exhibit two of the 15 strips. The exhibition was attended by thousands.
However, Clermont-Ganneau also attended the exhibition; Shapira had denied him access to the other 13 strips. After close examination, Clermont-Ganneau declared them to be forgeries. Soon afterward British biblical scholar [[Christian David Ginsburg]] came to the same conclusion. Later Clermont-Ganneau showed that the leather of the Deuteronomy scroll was quite possibly cut from the margin of a genuine Yemenite scroll that Shapira had previously sold to the Museum.
Shapira fled London in despair, his name ruined and all of his hopes crushed. Six months later, on March 9, 1884, he shot himself in Hotel Bloemendaal in [[Rotterdam]].
The Shapira Strips disappeared and then reappeared a couple of years later in a [[Sotheby's]] auction, where they were sold for 10 [[guinea coin|guinea]]s. In 1899 they were probably destroyed in a fire at the house of the presumed final owner, Sir [[Charles Nicholson]].
===No new final evidence=== Despite the assessment of contemporary scholars - German ones from Halle, Leipzig and Berlin, Clermont-Ganneau from France, Christian David Ginsburg of London - declaring with good arguments either that the leather had only been recently processed, or that the Hebrew script and language used were flawed, and even leaving aside the fact that the peculiar "eleventh commandment" showed Christian leanings which could be connected to Shapira's own conversion, there have always been researchers claiming to have reasons to believe that the Deuteronomy scroll might be a genuine ancient artifact after all. The presumed but hard to prove physical loss of the strips in the 1899 fire leaves space for speculation, but none for actual research.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paleojudaica.blogspot.co.il/2013_11_03_archive.html#810475699851573000 |title=The Shapira forgeries raise their moldering heads again |author=James R. Davila, PhD, Professor of Early Jewish Studies |date=2013-11-03 |accessdate=2014-12-06 }}</ref> There are no major scholars dealing with the issue currently, especially since nobody has produced any surviving fragment of the strips, the only useful facsimile being the well-known one created by Ginsburg back in 1883. The fact is also that contemporary press articles which ridiculed Shapira using anti-Semitic stereotypes did not precede, but rather followed the rejection of the scroll by a large range of scholars.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Oskar K. Rabinowicz |date=July 1965 |title=The Shapira Scroll: An nineteenth-century forgery |journal=The Jewish Quarterly Review: New Series|volume=56 |issue=1 |pages=1–21 |jstor=1453329 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/appendixjournal-images/images/attachments/000/001/415/large/Punch6.jpg |title=Mr. Sharp-Eye-Ra (cartoon) |work=[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]] |date=September 1883 |accessdate=2014-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219120716/http://s3.amazonaws.com/appendixjournal-images/images/attachments/000/001/415/large/Punch6.jpg |archivedate=2014-12-19 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Press |first=Michael |title="The Lying Pen of the Scribes": A Nineteenth-Century Dead Sea Scroll |journal=The Appendix |date=July 1214 |volume= 2| issue = 3|url=http://theappendix.net/issues/2014/7/the-lying-pen-of-the-scribes-a-nineteenth-century-dead-sea-scroll|accessdate=2014-12-08 }}</ref>
==Heritage== Shapira "Moabitica" fakes still exist in museums and private collections around the world but are rarely displayed. By now they have become desirable collectibles in their own right.
The exact location of Shapira's shop on Christian Quarter Road in Jerusalem has now been identified.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Guil|first=Shlomo|title=In the Footsteps of the Concealed Shop|journal=Et Mol|date=June 2012|volume=223}} Online reference https://www.academia.edu/2127379/In_Search_of_the_Shop_of_Moses_Wilhelm_Shapira_the_Leading_Figure_of_the_19TH_Century_Archaeological_Enigma</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
*Guil, Shlomo (March 2017) ."[https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00310328.2016.1185895 The Shapira Scroll was an Authentic Dead Sea Scroll]". Palestine Exploration Quarterly. Vol.149, No.1, pp.6-27.
== Further reading == * E. F. Kautzsch and A. Socin, ''Die Echtheit der moabitischen Altertümer geprüft'' (1876) * [http://tabletmag.com/podcasts/182217/faking-it-israel-story-1 "Faking it"] - Radio piece on Shapira produced by Israel story podcast for [[Tablet (magazine)|Tablet Magazine]] , 18 August 2014. * Tigay, Chanan, ''The Lost Book of Moses'' (2016) {{ISBN|0062206419}}

[[New Zealand Order of Merit|ONZM]] (2014) | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} '''Michael John Nigel Priestley''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|ONZM|size=85%}} (21 July 1943 – 23 December 2014) was a New Zealand earthquake engineer. He made significant contributions to the design and retrofit of concrete structures, and developed the first displacement-based method of seismic design. ==Early life and education== Born in [[Wellington]] in 1943,{{cite book |last=Calvi |first=Gian Michele | chapter=Engineers understanding of earthquakes demand and structures response |authorlink= |title=Earthquake engineering in Europe |editor1-last=Garevski |editor1-first=Mihail |editor2-last=Ansal |editor2-first=Atilla |url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=vtcnifItey4C&pg=PA238 |accessdate=24 February 2015 |year=2010 |publisher=Springer |location=Dordrecht |isbn=978-90-481-9544-2 |pages=238–239}} Priestley was educated at [[Wellington High School (New Zealand)|Wellington Technical College]] from 1956 to 1959.{{cite web |url=http://www.whs.school.nz/alumni/wall-of-high-achievers/4/ |title=Wall of high achievers |date= |website= |publisher=Wellington High School |accessdate=25 January 2015}} When aged 16 he began studying civil engineering at the [[University of Canterbury]], completing a [[Bachelor of Engineering]] with first-class honours and, in 1966, a [[PhD]].{{cite web |url= http://www.nzsee.org.nz/membership/distinguished-members/nigel-priestley/ |title=Nigel Priestley – life membership citation |date= |website= |publisher=New Zealand Society for Earthquake Engineering Inc. |accessdate=24 February 2015}} His thesis was titled ''Moment redistribution in prestressed concrete continuous beams''. ==Professional and academic career== From 1967 to 1975 Priestley was the head of the structures laboratory at the [[New Zealand Ministry of Works|Ministry of Works and Development]] central laboratories in [[Lower Hutt]], where he led structural studies of bridges and buildings. In 1976 he returned to the University of Canterbury where he was a senior lecturer and then [[Reader (academic rank)|reader]] in the Department of Civil Engineering. Over the next 10 years he conducted research into the seismic behaviour of masonry structures in collaboration with [[Thomas Paulay|Tom Paulay]], and reinforced concrete columns in collaboration with Bob Park. He was also the consulting proof engineer for many major rail bridges and industrial buildings in New Zealand. He served as president of the New Zealand Society for Earthquake Engineering from 1985 to 1986.{{cite web |url=http://canterbury.royalcommission.govt.nz/documents-by-key/20111128.1320/$File/WIT.PRI.0001.pdf |title=Curriculum vitae for Nigel Priestley |date=28 November 2011 |website= |publisher=Royal Commission of Inquiry into Building Failure Caused by the Canterbury Earthquakes |accessdate=24 February 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.iaee.or.jp/pdf/PriestleyObituary.pdf |title=Obituary for Professor Nigel Priestley |date= |website= |publisher=International Association for Earthquake Engineering |accessdate=26 February 2015 | first=Gregory | last= MacRae}} Priestley was then professor of structural engineering at the [[University of California, San Diego]] (UCSD) from 1987 until 2000. During this time his research focused on the seismic design of concrete bridges. In the wake of the [[1989 Loma Prieta earthquake]] and the [[1994 Northridge earthquake]] he was a member of various [[California Department of Transportation]] (Caltrans) committees and commissions reviewing the design of damaged bridges, and was also a member or chair of a number of Caltrans committees investigating the seismic strengthening of existing structures. He became professor emeritus of structural engineering at UCSD in 2001. He co-founded the European School for Advanced Studies in Reduction of Seismic Risk (ROSE School) in [[Pavia]], Italy, with Gian Michele Calvi, and served as its co-director from 2002 to 2008, and emeritus co-director from 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.roseschool.it/news/2014/12/93/professor-m-j-n-priestley-1943-2014.html |title=Professor M.J.N. Priestley (1943–2014) |date= |website= |publisher=ROSE School |accessdate=26 February 2015}} Following the [[2010 Canterbury earthquake]] and [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]], Priestley was an expert witness before the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Building Failure Caused by the Canterbury Earthquakes, and chaired a panel that investigated the collapse of the [[CTV Building]] and PGC Building, and damage to the [[Hotel Grand Chancellor, Christchurch|Hotel Grand Chancellor]] and [[Forsyth Barr Building, Christchurch|Forsyth Barr Building]].{{cite news | url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/64515955/Nigel-Priestley-Luminary-engineer-dies | title=Nigel Priestley - 'Luminary' engineer dies | date= 29 December 2014 | work=The Press | accessdate=26 February 2015}} Priestley died in Christchurch of cancer on 23 December 2014. ==Legacy== Priestley was author or co-author of over 450 scientific papers and 250 research reports, and was the primary advisor for more than 25 doctoral students. His three books: {{Bulleted list| ''Seismic Design of Concrete and Masonry Buildings'' with Tom Paulay (1992) |''Seismic Design and Retrofit of Bridges'' with [[Frieder Seible]] and Gian Michele Calvi (1996) |''Displacement-Based Seismic Design of Structures'' with Gian Michele Calvi and Mervyn Kowalsky (2007) }} are regarded as canonical texts in their particular areas. His research at UCSD with Frieder Seible following the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake into structural deficiencies in reinforced concrete columns supported bridges in California led to the development an economical retrofit solution involving the installation of a metal jacket to reduce the risk of column failure in seismic events.{{cite journal |last=Priestley |first=M. J. Nigel |last2=Seible |first2=Frieder |date=September 1992 |title=Research into seismic retrofit of reinforced concrete column bridges |url=http://www.nzsee.org.nz/db/Bulletin/Archive/25(3)0203.pdf |journal=Bulletin of the New Zealand National Society for Earthquake Engineering |publisher= |volume=25 |issue=3 |pages=203–210 |doi= |accessdate=26 February 2015}}{{cite journal |last=Priestley |first=Rebecca |date=22 January 2015 |title=A tribute to my father, Nigel Priestley (1943–2015) |url=http://www.roseschool.it/news/2015/02/94/tribute-to-prof-nigel-priestley-by-rebecca-priestley.html |journal=The Listener |publisher= |volume= |issue=3898 |pages= |doi= |accessdate=26 February 2015}} The method has been widely adopted, particularly on the west coast of the United States.{{cite web |url=http://crosscut.com/2014/09/bridges-earthquakes-seismic-retrofit-washington/ |title=Funding shaky for state program to earthquake-proof bridges |date=4 September 2014 |website= |publisher=Crosscut |accessdate=26 February 2015 | first=Bill | last=Lucia}} A team led by Priestley developed PRESSS (precast seismic structural system), a design methodology for earthquake-resistant buildings in which the building is designed as a collection of rocking blocks able to move independently of each other during a seismic event but are pulled back into their original position by unbonded post-tensioning cables within the precast concrete structure.{{cite web |url=http://www.manufacturerssuccessconnection.co.nz/mscnewswire/25373-new-zealand-civil-engineer-nigel-priestley-was-among-the-outstanding-seismic-constructors-of-his-era.html |title=New Zealander Nigel Priestley co-founded graduate earthquake engineer school in Pavia, Italy |date=30 January 2015 |website= |publisher=MSC NewsWire |accessdate=26 February 2015}} Priestley eschewed force-based design methods for earthquake-resistant buildings and developed the first method for displacement-based design, an approach that has been described as revolutionary. Traditional force-based methods could not adequately describe the expected damage, or performance, of a building subjected to seismic forces, whereas Priestley's displacement-based approach allows engineers to dictate the behaviour of a building in an earthquake. ==Honours and awards== Priestley was conferred honorary doctorates by [[ETH Zurich]] and the [[National University of Cuyo]], Argentina. He was a Fellow of the [[Institution of Professional Engineers New Zealand]] (IPENZ), the [[American Concrete Institute]] (ACI), and the New Zealand Society for Earthquake Engineering. In 1999 he was elected an honorary [[Fellow of the Royal Society of New Zealand]].{{cite web |url=http://www.royalsociety.org.nz/organisation/academy/fellowship/list-of-honorary-fellows-1870-present/p-r/ |title=The Academy: honorary fellows P–R |date= |website= |publisher=Royal Society of New Zealand |accessdate=26 February 2015}} He won over 30 national and international awards for his research and technical papers, including the Fulton Gold Medal from IPENZ in 1973, the Raymond C. Reese Award from the ACI in 1984 and 1989, and the Freyssinet Medal from the [[International Federation for Structural Concrete|fib]] in 2010. In the [[2014 Birthday Honours (New Zealand)|2014 Queen's Birthday Honours]], Priestley was appointed an [[New Zealand Order of Merit|Officer of the New Zealand Order of Merit]], for services to structural engineering.{{cite web |url=https://www.dpmc.govt.nz/publications/queens-birthday-honours-list-2014 |title=Queen's Birthday honours list 2014 |date=2 June 2014 |publisher=Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet |accessdate=28 April 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Christchurch earthquakes}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Priestley, Nigel}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:People from Wellington City]] [[Category:People educated at Wellington High School, New Zealand]] [[Category:University of Canterbury alumni]] [[Category:New Zealand civil engineers]] [[Category:New Zealand public servants]] [[Category:University of Canterbury faculty]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:University of California, San Diego faculty]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriates in Italy]] [[Category:Officers of the New Zealand Order of Merit]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of New Zealand]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New Zealand]] [[Category:ETH Zurich]] [[Category:People associated with the 2011 Christchurch earthquake]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox military person | name = Oliver Sipple | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1941|11|20}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1989|02|02|1941|11|20}} | birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | death_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | placeofburial = [[Golden Gate National Cemetery]] | birth_name = Oliver Wellington Sipple | allegiance = [[United States]] | branch = [[United States Marine Corps]] | serviceyears = | rank = [[Private First Class#United States Marine Corps|PFC]] }}
'''Oliver Wellington "Billy" Sipple''' (November 20, 1941 – February 2, 1989) was a decorated U.S. [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] and [[Vietnam War]] veteran. On September 22, 1975, he grappled with [[Sara Jane Moore]] as she fired a pistol at [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Gerald Ford]] in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], causing her to miss. The subsequent public revelation that Sipple was [[gay]] turned the news story into a [[cause célèbre]] for [[LGBT]] rights activists, leading Sipple to unsuccessfully sue several publishers for [[Privacy laws of the United States|invasion of privacy]].
==Early life== Oliver Wellington Sipple was born in [[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]]. He served in the [[United States Marine Corps]] and fought in [[Vietnam]]. [[Fragmentation (weaponry)|Shrapnel]] wounds suffered in December 1968 caused him to finish out his tour of duty in a [[Philadelphia]] veterans' hospital, from which he was released in March 1970. Sipple, who was [[closeted]] in his hometown of [[Detroit]], had met [[Harvey Milk]] in [[New York City]] and had participated in San Francisco's [[pride parade|gay pride parades]] and [[gay rights]] demonstrations.<ref name="News And Sexuality: Medi" /><ref name="Conduct Unbecoming: Ga">{{cite book |last=Shilts |first=Randy |authorlink=Randy Shilts |title=Conduct Unbecoming: Gays and Lesbians in the U.S. Military |publisher=Macmillan |isbn=978-0-312-34264-7 |year=2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iOAmL6JPCE0C&dq=%22Oliver+Sipple%22+%22harvey+milk%22&q=sipple#v=snippet&q=sipple&f=false |accessdate=2008-02-19}}</ref> Sipple was active in local causes, including the historic political campaigns of openly gay Board of Supervisors candidate Milk. The two were friends and Sipple would also be later described as a "prominent figure" in the gay community who had worked in a gay bar and was active in the [[Imperial Court System]].<ref name="Electronic Media Law">{{cite book |last=Sadler |first=Roger L. |title=Electronic Media Law |publisher=Sage Publications Inc. |isbn=978-1-4129-0588-6 |year=2005 |url=https://books.google.com/booksd=i4egPXh4OoEC&dq=%22Oliver+Sipple%22+%22harvey+milk%22&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0 |accessdate=2008-02-19}}</ref><ref name="Outing: Shattering the">{{cite book |last=Johansson |first=Warren |author2=William A. Percy |title=Outing: Shattering the Conspiracy of Silence |publisher=Haworth Press |isbn=978-1-56024-419-6 |year=1994 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=-lZ903C-dkMC&dq=%22Oliver+Sipple%22+%22harvey+milk%22 |accessdate=2008-02-19}}</ref>
He lived with a merchant seaman in a fourth-floor walk-up apartment located in San Francisco's [[Mission District, San Francisco, California|Mission District]]. He later spent six months in San Francisco's [[Veterans Health Administration|VA hospital]], and was frequently readmitted into the hospital in 1975, the year he saved Ford's life.
==Ford assassination attempt== Sipple was part of a crowd of about 3,000 people who had gathered outside San Francisco's [[St. Francis Hotel]] to see President Ford on September 22, 1975. Ford, just emerging from the building, was vulnerable despite heavy security protection. Standing beside Sipple in the crowd, was [[Sara Jane Moore]]. She was about 40 feet (12 m) away from President Ford when she fired a single shot at him with a revolver, narrowly missing the President.<ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=Radiolab Podcast|title=Radiolab - Oliver Sipple [Daryl Lembke, Daniel Luzer, Ken Maley, Sarah Jane Moore, Dan Morain]|date=2017-09-23|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lkLy2P3_Q1g|accessdate=2017-10-03}}</ref> After realizing she had missed, she raised her arm again, and Sipple dived towards her; he grabbed her arm, possibly saving President Ford's life. Sipple said at the time, "I saw [her gun] pointed out there and I grabbed for it. [...] I lunged and grabbed the woman's arm and the gun went off."<ref name=":0" /><ref name="latimes2/13/89" /> The bullet ricocheted and hit John Ludwig, a 42-year-old taxi driver; he survived.<ref name="WaPo" /> The incident came just three weeks after [[Lynette Fromme]]'s [[Gerald Ford assassination attempt in Sacramento|assassination attempt]] on Ford. Reporters hounded Sipple who at first did not want his name used, nor his location known.<ref name="News And Sexuality: Medi" />
==Aftermath== The police and the [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] immediately commended Sipple for his action at the scene, as did the media.<ref name="News And Sexuality: Medi">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UrEIJ2MzMtYC|title=News And Sexuality: Media Portraits of Diversity|last=Castañeda|first=Laura|author2=Shannon B. Campbell|publisher=Sage Publications Inc|year=2006|isbn=978-1-4129-0999-0|location=|pages=|accessdate=2008-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lambda.net/~maximum/sipple.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831033508/http://www.lambda.net/~maximum/sipple.html |archivedate=August 31, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} "Oliver Sipple 1941-1989". Accessed May 23, 2007.</ref> The national news media portrayed Sipple as a hero, and noted his status as a former Marine.<ref>[http://www.lambda.net/~maximum/sipple.html "Oliver Sipple 1941–1989"]. Accessed May 23, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213022926/http://www.lambda.net/~maximum/sipple.html |date=February 13, 2007 }}</ref>
Though he was known to be homosexual among members of the San Francisco gay community, and had even participated in [[gay pride]] events, Sipple's sexual orientation was a secret from his family. He asked the press to keep such personal information off the record, making it clear that neither his mother nor his employer knew he was gay.<ref name="Shilts">[[Randy Shilts|Shilts, Randy]] (1982). ''The Mayor of Castro Street: The Life and Times of Harvey Milk'', St. Martin's Press. {{ISBN|0-312-52330-0}} p. 122.</ref>
The day after the incident, two [[answering machine]] messages [[outed]] Sipple to ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'s'' columnist [[Herb Caen]]. One was from Reverend Ray Broshears, the head of a gay activist group called the Lavender Panthers.<ref name="radiolab">[http://www.radiolab.org/story/oliver-sipple/ Oliver Sipple - Radiolab] especially from around 16:30 to 20:00</ref> The other message was from local gay activist [[Harvey Milk]], a friend of Sipple and on whose campaign for city council Sipple had worked.<ref name="radiolab" /> While discussing whether the truth about Sipple's sexuality should be disclosed, Milk told a friend, "It's too good an opportunity. For once we can show that gays do heroic things, not just all that caca about molesting children and hanging out in bathrooms."<ref name="Shilts"/> Milk outed Sipple in order to portray him as a "gay hero" and so to "break the stereotype of homosexuals" being "timid, weak and unheroic figures".<ref name="Conduct Unbecoming: Ga" /><ref name="Electronic Media Law" /><ref name="latimes2/13/89">Morain, Dan (February 13, 1989). [http://www.latimes.com/news/me-ford2,0,2563533,full.story "Sorrow Trailed a Veteran Who Saved a President and Then Was Cast in an Unwanted Spotlight"], ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'', p. 1. {{dead link|date=July 2010}}</ref> According to Harold Evans, "[T]here was no invitation to the White House for Sipple, not even a commendation. Milk made a fuss about that. Finally, weeks later, Sipple received a brief note of thanks."<ref>Harold Evans, ''The Imperial Presidency: 1972–1980', Random House, 1998.</ref>
Two days after the thwarted assassination attempt, unable to reach Sipple,<ref name="radiolab" /> Caen wrote of Sipple as a gay man, and of a friend of Milk, speculating Ford offered praise "quietly" because of Sipple's sexual orientation. Sipple was besieged by reporters, as was his family. His mother refused to speak to him. [[Gay liberation]] groups petitioned local media to give Sipple his due as a gay hero. Caen published the private side of the Marine's story, as did a handful of other publications.<ref name="Electronic Media Law" /> Sipple then insisted to reporters that his sexuality was to be kept confidential.<ref name="News And Sexuality: Medi" /> Reporters labeled Sipple the "gay ex-Marine", and his mother disparaged and disowned him.<ref name="Outing: Shattering the" /> Later, when Sipple hid in a friend's apartment to avoid them, the reporters turned to Milk, arguably the most visible voice for the gay community.<ref name="News And Sexuality: Medi" /> Of President Ford's letter of thanks to Sipple, Milk suggested that Sipple's sexual orientation was the reason he received only a note, rather than an invitation to the [[White House]].<ref name="latimes2/13/89" />
Sipple sued the ''Chronicle'',<ref name="WaPo" /> filing a $15-million [[Privacy law|invasion of privacy]] suit against Caen, seven named newspapers, and a number of unnamed publishers, for publishing the disclosures. The Superior Court in San Francisco dismissed the suit, and Sipple continued his legal battle until May 1984, when a state court of appeals held that Sipple had indeed become news, and that his sexual orientation was part of the story.<ref name="latimes2/13/89" />
==Later years and death== According to a 2006 article in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', Sipple went through a period of estrangement with his parents, but the family later reconciled with him. Sipple's brother, George, told the newspaper, "[Our parents] accepted it. That was all. They didn't like it, but they still accepted. He was welcomed. Only thing was: Don't bring a lot of your friends."<ref name="WaPo">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/30/AR2006123000160.html Caught in Fate's Trajectory, Along With Gerald Ford], Lynne Duke, ''[[The Washington Post]]'', December 30, 2006, p. D01.</ref> However other sources indicate that Sipple's parents never fully accepted him. His mother, just after news broke of Sipple's sexual orientation, hung up on Sipple saying she never wished to speak to him again. His father is said to have told Sipple's brother to "forget [he had] a brother." Finally, when his mother died, his father did not allow him to attend her funeral.<ref name="radiolab.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.radiolab.org/story/oliver-sipple/|title=Oliver Sipple - Radiolab - WNYC Studios|publisher=|accessdate=September 9, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Oliver W. Sipple headstone.JPG|thumb|Sipple's headstone at Golden Gate National Cemetery]] Sipple's mental and physical health sharply declined over the years. He drank heavily, was diagnosed with [[schizophrenia]], fitted with a pacemaker, and gained weight.<ref name="articles.latimes.com">{{Cite newspaper|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-02-13/news/vw-1568_1_gay-big-deal-jerry-ford|title=Sorrow Trailed a Veteran Who Saved a President and Then Was Cast in an Unwanted Spotlight|journal=Los Angeles Times|first=DAN|last=MORAIN|date=February 13, 1989|accessdate=September 9, 2018|via=LA Times}}</ref><ref>{{Cite newspaper|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/04/obituaries/ow-sipple-47-who-blocked-an-attempt-to-kill-ford-in-1975.html?mcubz=1|title=O.W. Sipple, 47, Who Blocked An Attempt To Kill Ford in 1975|journal=The New York Times|first=Jesus|last=Rangel|accessdate=September 9, 2018|date=1989-02-04}}</ref> The incident brought him so much attention that, later in life, while drinking, he would express regret about grabbing Moore's gun. On February 2, 1989, an acquaintance, Wayne Friday, found Sipple dead in his San Francisco apartment, with a bottle of [[Jack Daniel's]] next to him and the television still on.<ref name="radiolab.org"/><ref name="articles.latimes.com"/> The San Francisco coroner estimated Sipple had been dead for approximately 10 days.<ref name="radiolab.org"/> He was 47 years old. Sipple's funeral was attended by about 30 people.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} President Ford and his wife sent a letter of sympathy to his family and friends. He was buried in [[Golden Gate National Cemetery]] south of San Francisco.
His $334 per month apartment near San Francisco's [[Tenderloin, San Francisco, California|Tenderloin District]] was found with many newspaper clippings of his actions on the fateful September afternoon in 1975, including a framed letter from the White House. A letter addressed to the friends of Oliver Sipple was on display for a short period after his death at the New Belle Saloon:
{{Quote|Mrs. Ford and I express our deepest sympathy in this time of sorrow involving your friend's passing... –Former President Gerald Ford, February, 1989}}
In a 2001 interview with columnist Deb Price, Ford disputed the claim that Sipple was treated differently because of his sexual orientation, saying,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://freedomtoserve.blogspot.com/2006/12/president-committed-to-unity.html|title=The Frontlines: A President Committed to 'Unity'|publisher=}}</ref>
{{Quote|As far as I was concerned, I had done the right thing and the matter was ended. I didn't learn until sometime later – I can't remember when – he was gay. I don't know where anyone got the crazy idea I was prejudiced and wanted to exclude gays.}}
==Legacy== According to Castañeda and Campbell:
{{quote|The Sipple incident has been referred to, in passing, in a major motion picture and in a prime-time television program. Several law review articles and more than a dozen books and commentary pieces have also mentioned the perplexing ethical dimensions of the case.<ref>Laura Castañeda, Shannon B. Campbell, "News and Sexuality: Media Portraits of Diversity", SAGE, 2006, {{ISBN|1-4129-0999-6}}, page 66. The movie referenced (chapter notes in the book) is ''[[Absence of Malice]]'', and the TV program is an episode from ''[[L.A. Law]]'' from May 1990.</ref>}}
A September 2017 episode of the radio program ''[[Radiolab]]'' covered Sipple's act of foiling the assassination of then President Ford. The episode goes into Sipple's act of heroism, his outing by [[Harvey Milk]] and [[Herb Caen]] and the news media, and the ethics of his outing in spite of his opposition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wbez.org/shows/radiolab/oliver-sipple/3022e3dc-c854-493c-b26e-3dae0273a3bc|title=Radiolab, Oliver Sipple|last=|first=|date=September 22, 2017|website=[[WBEZ|WBEZ 91.5]] [[Chicago]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170922232947/https://www.wbez.org/shows/radiolab/oliver-sipple/3022e3dc-c854-493c-b26e-3dae0273a3bc|archive-date=September 22, 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=}}</ref>

{{For|similar terms|Order of St. Thomas (disambiguation){{!}}Order of St. Thomas}}
The '''Order of St. Thomas''' is the highest honorary award given by the [[Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church|Indian Orthodox Church]] and named after [[Thomas the Apostle|St. Thomas the Apostle]] who founded the Church in India. It is reserved for heads of states and churches and awarded by the [[Catholicos of the East and Malankara Metropolitan]], who is the primate of the Indian Orthodox Church and successor to St. Thomas the Apostle. The award is usually presented at large public gatherings held at different locations of importance to the Indian Orthodox Church within India.
==Recipients== ===1. Gyani Zail Singh, President of India (1982)===
During the Catholicate [[Platinum jubilee]] celebratory meeting<ref>{{cite book |last= Thomas|first= Dr. M. Kurian|date= November 2016|series =വട്ടക്കുന്നേൽ മാത്യൂസ് റാബോ കാതോലിക്കാ | volume = I|title= ആത്മകഥ, പഠനങ്ങൾ, ചിത്രങ്ങൾ|trans-title=Vattakkunnel Mathews Rabo Catholicos (Vol. I) - Autobiography, Research and Pictures| language= Malayalam|location= India|publisher= MOC Publications, Kottayam| pages = 130–133|isbn= |accessdate= }}</ref> held at [[Kottayam]] [[Nehru Stadium, Kottayam|Nehru Stadium]] on 12 September 1982, the chief guest [[Zail Singh|Gyani Zail Singh]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://notknowingyourhistoryisnotknowingyourself.wordpress.com/2018/09/16/order-of-st-thomas/|title=Order Of St. Thomas - newspaper reports, pictures and references|website=www.notknowingyourhistoryisnotknowingyourself.wordpress.com}}</ref>, President of India, was awarded the Order of St. Thomas by Catholicos His Holiness [[Baselios Mar Thoma Mathews I|Baselios MarThoma Mathews I]]. Dignitaries from several Churches around the world were present at the meeting including [[Catholicos of All Armenians]] [[Vazgen I]] and [[Catholicos-Patriarch of All Georgia]] [[Ilia II of Georgia|Ilia II]]. [[P. C. Alexander|Dr. P. C. Alexander]], Principal Secretary to the Prime Minister of India and Union Minister [[C. M. Stephen]] were among the guests at this immense meeting. [[Paulos Gregorios|Dr. Paulos Mar Gregorios]], Catholicos Designate [[Baselios Mar Thoma Mathews II|Mathews Mar Coorilos]], [[List of Governors of Andhra Pradesh|Governor of Andhra Pradesh]] [[K. C. Abraham]], Michael Bosco Duraisamy of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Salem|Salem]] representing the Pope of Rome, Metropolitan [[Emilianos Zacharopoulos|Emilianos]] representing the [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople]], Metropolitan Nathaniel of [[Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church|Ethiopian Orthodox Church]], Metropolitan Vladimir of [[Russian Orthodox Church]], Metropolitan Sairadhariar of [[Armenian Apostolic Church|Armenian Orthodox Church]], Metropolitan Nestor of [[Romanian Orthodox Church]], Bishop Josif Velichki of [[Bulgarian Orthodox Church]], Bishop Ambrosius of [[Finland]], [[Kerala]] state minister [[R. Balakrishna Pillai]] and Chief Editor of [[Malayala Manorama]] Mr. [[K. M. Mathew]] were also present on the occasion.
===2. Bartholomew I, Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople (2000)=== On 19 November 2000, the [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople]] [[Bartholomew I of Constantinople|His All Holiness Bartholomew I]] was awarded the Order of St. Thomas by Catholicos His Holiness [[Baselios Mar Thoma Mathews II|Baselios Marthoma Mathews II]] at [[Parumala Seminary]]<ref>{{cite web|title=ORDER OF ST THOMAS Award Winners|last=Thottapuzha|first=Verghis John|url=http://malankaraorthodox.tv/?p=62396|archive-date = 1 August 2018}}</ref>.
===3. Karekin II Nersessian, Supreme Patriarch & Catholicos of all Armenians (2008)=== On 6 November 2008, the [[Catholicos of All Armenians|Supreme Patriarch & Catholicos of all Armenians]] [[Karekin II|His Holiness Karekin II Nersessian]]<ref>{{Citation | last = Staff Reporter | first = | author-link = | title =Armenian Church Head to be Honoured | newspaper = The Hindu | pages = | year = 2008 | date =6 November 2008 | url =https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/Armenian-Church-head-to-be-honoured/article15336210.ece | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | first = Verghis John | last = Thottapuzha | title = മലങ്കര ഓർത്തഡോക്സ് സഭ പരമോന്നത ബഹുമതിയായ ഓർഡർ ഓഫ് സെൻറ് തോമസ് നൽകി ആദരിച്ചവർ | periodical = Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church - The Online Official News Bulletin | language = Malayalam | volume = 31 | pages = 12 | year = 2018 | date = 4 August 2018|trans-title=List of those conferred with Order of St. Thomas, the highest honorary title bestowed by Malankara Orthodox Church|location= India|publisher= MOSC Media Department | url = https://ia902900.us.archive.org/18/items/orthodox_news_letter_Vol_1_No_31/orthodox_news_letter_Vol_1_No_31.pdf | archive-date = | access-date = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Staff Reporter | first = | author-link = | title =Armenian Catholicos Honoured | newspaper = The Hindu | pages = | year = 2008 | date =7 November 2008 | url =https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/Armenian-Catholicos-honoured/article15337100.ece | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = }}</ref> was awarded the Order of St. Thomas by Catholicos His Holiness [[Baselios Marthoma Didymos I|Baselios Marthoma Didymos I]] at Mammen Mappila Hall, [[Kottayam]]. The dignitaries who were present at the public meeting included Armenian Ambassador to India Ashot Kocharian,<ref name="orthodoxchristianity">{{cite web|url=http://www.orthodoxchristianity.net/forum/index.php?topic=18048.0|website=orthodoxchristianity.net|title=Armenian Catholicos to visit Indian Church|quote=His Holiness Karekin II The Supreme Patriarch and Catholicos of All Armenians will visit the Malankara Orthodox Church and her head His Holiness Moran Mar Baselios Marthoma Didymus I, The Catholicos of the East & Malankara Metropolitan from Nov 5-8. His Holiness Karekin II will be accompanied by His Eminence Archbishop Aghan Baliozian, Primate of the Armenian Church Diocese of Australia, His Excellency Dr. Ashot Kocharian, Ambassador of the Republic of Armenia in India, etc... His Holiness Karekin II will be confered the Order of St. Thomas by His Holiness the Catholicos of the East, in a function at Mammen Mappilai Hall on 6th.|accessdate=2018-08-09}}</ref> Catholicos Designate [[Baselios Mar Thoma Paulose II|Paulos Mar Milithios]], Thomas Mar Athanasius of [[Chengannur]], Knanaya Catholic Archbishop [[Mathew Moolakkatt]] of Kottayam and [[Priest Trustee]] Rev. Dr. Johns Abraham Konat among others.
===4. Abune Paulos, Patriarch of Ethiopia (2008)=== On 30 December 2008, the [[List of Abunas of Ethiopia|Patriarch of Ethiopia]] [[Abune Paulos|His Holiness Abune Paulos]]<ref>{{cite web | url =http://orientalorthodoxy.blogspot.com/2009/01/ethiopian-delegation-visits-malankara.html| title =Ethiopian Patriarch visits Malankara Orthodox Church | last =| first =| date =12 January 2009 | website =www.orientalorthodoxy.blogspot.com | publisher = | access-date = |quote=The Ethiopian Patriarch was conferred the Order of St. Thomas by the Catholicose on the occasion.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gmic.co.uk/topic/60844-the-order-of-st-thomas-of-the-malankara-syriac-church/|title=The Order Of St. Thomas of the Malankara Syriac Church|website=www.gmic.co.uk}}</ref>{{unreliable source|date=September 2018}} was awarded the Order of St. Thomas by Catholicos His Holiness [[Baselios Marthoma Didymos I|Baselios Marthoma Didymos I]] at [[Parumala Seminary]]. During his visit to India, Abune Paulos was also the chief guest at the centenary celebrations of [[Mar Gregorios Orthodox Christian Student Movement|Mar Gregorios Orthodox Christian Student Movement (MGOCSM)]].
===5. Aram I Keshishian, Armenian Catholicos of Cilicia (2010)=== On 27 February 2010, the [[Holy See of Cilicia|Armenian Catholicos of Cilicia]] [[Aram I|His Holiness Aram I Keshishian]]<ref>{{cite book |last= Thevervelil|first= Tibin Chacko|date= May 2017|title= യൂബോൽ സബിനെ - മലങ്കരസഭാ ദിനവൃത്താന്തം|trans-title=Yubol Sabine - Chronicle of Malankara Church| language= Malayalam|location= India|publisher= Thevervelil Publishers| pages = 56|isbn= |accessdate= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =http://bombayorthodoxdiocese.org/his-holiness-the-catholicos-of-the-east-to-lead-malankara-orthodox-delegation-on-100th-anniversary-of-armenian-genocide/ | title =His Holiness the Catholicos of the East to lead Malankara Orthodox delegation on 100th anniversary of Armenian Genocide | last =Philipose | first =Rev. Thomas | date =15 April 2015 | website =www.bombayorthodoxdiocese.org | publisher = Bombay Diocese of Malankara Orthodox Church | access-date = | quote =It may be recalled that the Armenian Catholicos Aram I was conferred with the ‘Order of St Thomas’ in February 2010 by LL Catholicos Baselios Marthoma Didymos I during his visit. ‘Order of St Thomas’ is the most prestigious honor by the Malankara Orthodox Church.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =http://malankaraorthodox.tv/?p=34571 | title =HH The Catholicos visiting the Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin | last =Thomas| first =Rev. Abraham| date =21 April 2015 | website =www.malankaraorthodox.tv | publisher = Ecumenical Relations Dept., Indian Orthodox Church | access-date = | quote =His Holiness Catholicos Karekin II was conferred with the Order of St. Thomas the prime honorific title of the Church by the then Catholicos of the Indian Orthodox Church His Holiness Baselios Marthoma Didymus I.}}</ref> was awarded the Order of St. Thomas by Catholicos His Holiness [[Baselios Marthoma Didymos I|Baselios Marthoma Didymos I]]<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.armradio.am/en/2015/04/15/catholicos-to-lead-indian-orthodox-church-delegation-on-100th-anniversary-of-armenian-genocide/| title =Catholicos to lead Indian Orthodox Church delegation on 100th anniversary of Armenian Genocide | last =Ghazanchyan | first =Siranush | date =15 April 2015 | website =www.armradio.am | publisher = Public Radio of Armenia | access-date = }}</ref> at [[St. Peter's College, Kolenchery|Kolencherry St. Peter's College]] Auditorium. The dignitaries who were present at the public meeting included Union Minister [[K. V. Thomas]], Catholicos Designate [[Baselios Mar Thoma Paulose II| Paulos Mar Milithios]], [[Philipose Mar Chrysostom|Philipos Mar Chrysostom]] of Mar Thoma Church, Yohannan Yosef of [[Chaldean Syrian Church|Chaldean Church]], Dr. Yakub Mar Irenios, Dr. Thomas Mar Athanasius, Dr. Mathews Mar Severios, Yuhanon Mar Polycarpos, Armenian Archbishop Sebo Sarkesian, Armenian bishop Nareg Alemisian, Rev. Mesros Sarkesian and [[Priest Trustee]] Rev. Dr. Johns Abraham Konat among others.
===6. Abune Mathias, Patriarch of Ethiopia (2016)=== On 24 November 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/kerala/2016/nov/20/ethiopian-patriarch-arrives-1540559.html|title=Ethiopian Patriarch arrives|publisher=The New Indian Express|date=20 November 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ezega.com/News/NewsDetails/3621/Patriarch-of-Ethiopia-Visiting-Kerala-India|title=Patriarch of Ethiopia Visiting Kerala, India|website=www.ezega.com}}</ref> the [[List of Abunas of Ethiopia|Patriarch of Ethiopia]] [[Abune Mathias|His Holiness Abune Mathias]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mosc.in/photo-gallery/order-of-st-thomas-to-his-holiness-abune-mathias-patriarch-ethiopian-orthodox-tewahedo-church|title=ORDER OF ST.THOMAS TO HIS HOLINESS ABUNE MATHIAS PATRIARCH ETHIOPIAN ORTHODOX TEWAHEDO CHURCH|website=www.mosc.in/photo-gallery}}</ref> was awarded the Order of St. Thomas by Catholicos His Holiness [[Baselios Mar Thoma Paulose II|Baselios Marthoma Paulos II]] at the chapel of [[Orthodox Theological Seminary, Kottayam|Orthodox Theological Seminary (Old Seminary), Kottayam]]. Abune Mathias was the chief guest for the bicentennial memorial feast of [[Mar Dionysius II|Pulikkottil Joseph Mar Dionysius I]] who established the Old Seminary in 1815 and the twentieth memorial feast of renowned theologian and philosopher [[Paulos Gregorios|Dr. Paulos Mar Gregorios]].

{{Use Canadian English|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox artist | name = Robert Charles Davidson | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|4 November 1946}} | birth_place = [[Hydaburg, Alaska]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Canadian | spouse = | field = carving, printmaking, painting, jewellery | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = | elected = | website = http://www.robertdavidson.ca/ | bgcolour = }}{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} '''Robert Charles Davidson''', [[Order of Canada|CM]], [[Order of British Columbia|OBC]] (born 4 November 1946 in [[Hydaburg, Alaska]]), is a [[Canada|Canadian]] artist of [[Haida people|Haida]] heritage. Davidson’s Haida name is ''Guud San Glans'', which means "Eagle of The Dawn". He is a leading figure in the renaissance of [[Haida art]] and culture.
==Life and work==
[[File:White Rock, BC - Haida totem pole 01.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Detail of "Gyaana", totem pole designed by Davidson and carved by him and others, Lions Lookout Park, [[White Rock, British Columbia]], Canada.]]
Davidson is known internationally as a carver of totem poles and masks, printmaker, painter and jeweller. He lives near Vancouver, working out of a studio on [[Semiahmoo First Nation]] land and making annual return visits to [[Haida Gwaii]].
His parents are [[Claude Davidson (Haida artist)|Claude]] and Vivian Davidson. Through Claude, he is the grandson of the Haida artist and memoirist [[Florence Davidson]]. He is a member of the Eagle [[Moiety (kinship)|moiety]], Ts'ał'lanas lineage. His younger brother and former apprentice, [[Reg Davidson]], is also a Haida carver.
In infancy, Robert Davidson moved with his family to the Haida village of [[Masset, British Columbia]], on [[Queen Charlotte Islands|Haida Gwaii (Queen Charlotte Islands)]]. For high school, he moved to [[Vancouver]] to attend [[Point Grey Secondary School]] in 1965. In 1966 he became apprenticed to the master Haida carver [[Bill Reid]]. In 1967 he began studies at the [[Emily Carr Institute of Art and Design|Vancouver School of Art]]. In 1969 he carved and raised the first totem pole on Haida Gwaii in approximately ninety years.
His works are included in the collections of the [[National Gallery of Canada]], the [[Canadian Museum of Civilization]] and the [[Vancouver Art Gallery]].<ref name=GG>{{cite web|title=Eight remarkable Canadians win Governor General’s Awards in Visual and Media Arts from the Canada Council for the Arts|url=http://canadacouncil.ca/en/media-arts/news-room/news/2010/governor-generals-awards-in-visual-and-media-arts-%282010%29|work=news release|publisher=Canada Council for the Arts|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref>
A significant solo exhibition of his work, ''Robert Davidson: The Abstract Edge'', was organized by the [[Museum of Anthropology]] at the [[University of British Columbia]] (UBC) for viewing at the [[National Gallery of Canada]] in [[Ottawa]] in 2007.
==Awards and recognition== * Honorary [[Doctor of Fine Arts]], [[University of Victoria]], 1992<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uvic.ca/universitysecretary/senate/honorary/recipients/index.php|title=Honorary degree recipients|publisher=University of Victoria|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> * Honorary [[Doctor of Laws]], [[Simon Fraser University]], 1994<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sfu.ca/ceremonies/honorary-degrees/past_honorary_degrees.html|title=Honorary degree recipients|publisher=Simon Fraser University|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> * [[Order of British Columbia]], 1995<ref>{{cite web|title=1995 Recipient: Robert Davidson – White Rock|url=http://www.orderofbc.gov.bc.ca/members/obc-1995/1995-robert-davidson/|work=Order of British Columbia|publisher=Province of British Columbia|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> * [[Indspire Awards|National Aboriginal Achievement Award]], now the Indspire Awards, 1995<ref>{{cite web|title=Mr. Robert Davidson|url=https://indspire.ca/laureates/robert-davidson/|work=Laureates|publisher=Indspire|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> * Member of the [[Order of Canada]], 1996<ref>{{cite web|title=Order of Canada Robert Davidson, C.M., O.B.C., D.F.A.(Hon)|url=http://archive.gg.ca/honours/search-recherche/honours-desc.asp?lang=e&TypeID=orc&id=3573|work=Honours|publisher=Governor General of Canada, Archives|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> * Honorary [[Doctor of Letters]] (D.Litt.), [[University of British Columbia]], 2007<ref name=UBCArchive>{{cite web|title=Honorary Degrees Conferred by UBC|url=http://www.library.ubc.ca/archives/honalpha.html|publisher=University of British Columbia|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> * Aboriginal Art Lifetime Achievement Awards, BC Achievement Foundation, 2007<ref name=BCAchieve>{{cite web|title=ABORIGINAL ARTISTS RECEIVE LIFETIME ACHIEVEMENT AWARDS|url=http://www2.news.gov.bc.ca/news_releases_2005-2009/2007OTP0077-000719.htm|work=news release|publisher=BC Achievement Foundation|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> * Governor General’s Awards in Visual and Media Arts, [[Canada Council]], 2010<ref name=GG/> * Member, [[Royal Canadian Academy of Arts]]<ref name=RCA1880>{{cite web|title=Members since 1880|url=http://www.rca-arc.ca/en/about_members/since1880.asp|publisher=Royal Canadian Academy of Arts|accessdate=11 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526215339/http://www.rca-arc.ca/en/about_members/since1880.asp|archivedate=26 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * The [[Audain Prize for Lifetime Achievement in the Visual Arts]], 2010<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/haida-artist-davidson-wins-b-c-s-audain-prize-1.945621|title=Haida artist Davidson wins B.C.'s Audain Prize|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-03-21|language=en}}</ref> {{Quotation|If we look at the world in the form of a circle, let us look at what is on the inside of the circle as experience, culture and knowledge: Let us look at this as the past. What is outside of the circle is yet to be experienced. But in order to expand the circle we must know what is inside the circle. |guud san glans, Robert Davidson<ref>{{cite web|title=Robert Davidson, Eagle of the Dawn Artist Ltd|url=http://www.robertdavidson.ca/|publisher=Eagle of the Dawn Artist Ltd|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> }}
